Single moms, when did you realise your kid wasn't as innocent as you thought? This generation is completely wack. I remember being 14 and still having braces and wearing ugly blue eyeshadow to school every day. But this was before social media, so all of my friends were just as ugly as me. But on my daughter's 15th birthday, we went out to Chili's, and what she wore was shocking. Not because it was anything crazy revealing. It was just a corset top and some cargo pants. It made me realize the pressure she had to grow up faster. She even did her makeup. And I swear, my baby Annalise looked 23 years old. And as we sat down, the waiter began to flirt with her. I wasn't really paying attention because I figured she'd turn him down or just act really shy. But in the corner of my eye, I saw her batting her eyes and looking up at him with a single finger twirling her hair. Motherly rage flooded my system. I literally saw the bulge in his pants. Hey, do you guys have a birthday candle with the No. 15? Because that's how old my daughter is turning today. Luckily, the guy went super red and started stammering, so I knew that he had simply been blindsided. And we even got switched to a new later. As for my daughter, I didn't want to ruin her birthday, so I let her change the topic, and we just Talked about something else. But when she woke up the next day, I asked her what the f she thought she was doing. That she could wear what she wanted, but there was no way I'd ever let her date anyone over the age of 17. We did that teenage angst thing where they pinch the bridge of their nose and roll their eyes like. It was the most original move in the book. So I grabbed her phone and unlocked it with her facial recognition. This time, something in her eyes changed. She begged me not to go through it. It was a good effort, but not good enough. I love you. And if you were a mother, you'd do the same thing. I then walked into my room and locked the door. There wasn't anything too bad. I did find what people call thirst traps on her TikTok, but her account was private and her following was mostly girls. The worrying part was her Instagram. There were bikini pictures plastered everywhere with extremely intimate songs and angles.

Lunch detention to shame me? Jokes on you, I'll sit here till the end of time. It was the late 90s. I was still drowning in flannel and keeping up my lifelong habit of hoarding library books way past their due date. I had a paper to write for my sophomore global studies class, so, of course, I checked out more books than I could possibly get through, wrote the essay, then totally forgot about the stack gathering dust in the corner of my room. After a steady stream of overdue notices showing up in my homeroom, I finally returned the four or five books one sunny afternoon via the anonymous drop box during a study hall, then promptly moved on to bigger and better things. About two weeks later, I was called down to the assistant principal's office. In that space of time before classes officially started that was reserved for one thing and one thing only. The reprobates and delinquents were in trouble. I walked the halls thinking that surely this was just a timing mishap, and I was being summoned to receive congratulations for some kind of award I didn't know I had entered into competition for. Yep, he just wants to prepare me for the surprise ticker tape parade. I was wholly unprepared to hear that I was receiving lunch detention to start immediately, because I had not returned a single book that I still remember was slim and had a white and red cover from My G S. Paper research. I tried to argue that there was a mistake, since I was sure, like I am sure that I have fingertips, I had returned it, but he could not be moved, and I was sentenced to indefinite lunch detention until I either return the book or paid the 16 bucks to replace it. I left the office late for first period, defeated, but kept my head held high at lunch later that day, as I walked past the entirety of the cafeteria, which held a couple hundred of my peers, plastic food tray in hand, I went down the hall to the old shop classroom that had since been moved and the awaiting detention. I checked in with missus brown at her desk in front and took an inconspicuous seat in the back, staring down at my canned peach slices. I braced for the worst. A murderous ruckus was going to break out any minute, I could tell. But once my ears stopped ringing, I discovered that it was really a calm escape from the crowded and rowdy.

He thought he was in control. Here, let me show you something. I'm driving to work a few months ago. Almost there. Two turns left, maybe half a mile total. Just neighborhood streets, nothing fancy. This guy in a black BMW crawls up my ass and stays there. I can see him in my mirror, phone in one hand, making these angry faces at me like I personally ruined his morning. I speed up a bit. 5 over the limit. He gets closer. Now he's maybe two feet from my bumper, still checking his phone every few seconds. Real genius move there, buddy. Anyway, I take the first turn, and now I'm on the street where my building is probably about 600 yards ahead. The assholes still tailing me, riding just inches from my bumper, and clearly pissed that I'm still sticking to the speed limit. Maybe around 35 on this stretch. So I press the gas a bit and sure enough, he matches my speed. I drive an 8 year old Toyota truck. Not huge, not tiny, just a regular truck that's seen some shit. All terrain tires, decent suspension, and I've definitely treated it like a truck should be treated. Pastures, rocks, curbs. My baby's been through it all. So as I'm getting closer to my building, there's this big speed bump in the road meant to slow people down before they reach the parking garage entrances. I plants back and yep, assholes still glued to my bumper. I remember thinking, I've got to ease up for this speed bump, and then thinking again, if I hit the brakes, this guy's gonna plow right into me. That's when the plan starts to form in my head. And I hit the gas. I'm going about 45 when I hit that speed bump and Yeehaw! Caught a little air and came down hard. Never even touched the brakes. Didn't tap him once. Gave him absolutely no heads up for what was coming. I'm locked on my rearview mirror through the whole thing cause I wanted to catch his reaction. He's got his phone.

I work at YouTube to take down disturbing content. After what I saw today, I'm quitting my job for good. Most people think YouTube is just a website to watch cat videos or makeup tutorials, but behind closed doors, there are thousands of disturbing videos that never make the homepage. It's my job to make sure it stays that way. You would think after watching thousands of these gruesome videos, I would build some type of tolerance. But after what I just saw on a random channel, I'm convinced that I'm gonna die soon. The channel was called marbles, and it didn't have a profile picture or bio, but what it did have were four videos with creepy titles and weird thumbnails. When I first saw the videos, I couldn't make out what the thumbnails were because the images were too pixelated. Thought it'd just be another person uploading abuse videos or someone making staged content to shock people, but I was dead wrong. The first video was titled doggy, and all it showed was just footage of a sleeping dog. No violence, no audio, and literally nothing. I watched it five times to see what the problem was, but I couldn't find anything, so I reinstated the video and moved on to the next one. But that's when things got creepier, because this video was titled six PM and it showed a man walking through a forest. His breathing was off and the camera was shaky, but then out Of nowhere, the video cut to him standing still while he wore a mask and stared down at the camera. His eyes didn't blink, and it felt like he was staring straight into my soul. The third video was called clouds, and this time the camera was pointed down while someone was lying on the ground with their legs cut off. He was screaming in pain for the first 30 seconds, but just when I thought I saw it all, he stopped screaming completely, looked directly at the camera, and whispered something before the video went black. I couldn't tell what he said because he was too quiet, but that didn't matter. The video clearly violated the terms of service, so I immediately removed the video and decided to watch the last one. The fourth video was called Bad Day, and this time the first three minutes were just footage of a blank white wall. I thought it would be a repeat of the first video where nothing happened, but right as I was about to click off the same.

I found a way to communicate with the afterlife. I'm now convinced I'm going to be dead tomorrow. I was just eating pizza a few nights ago when out of nowhere I got an email replying to my audio technician job listing on Craigslist. I was super excited to finally have some interest in my work, but when I saw that the pay was $100,000 for just three days of work, I was a bit skeptical. I thought this was just a fake email and was about to click off until I saw that there was an audio file attached underneath. We've listened to your samples and your sound processing skills are exactly what we're looking for. If you're interested in the job, please reply within 48 hours. Additionally, you will need to sign an NDA before you accept the position. After listening to the audio, I assumed I was just wrong about it being fake and decided I was willing to sign whatever I needed to. But the second I opened up the NDA to get some more details on the job, I found that one of the clauses said I would need to sign a waiver with a fine print saying that I might die. I had a bad feeling about it, but I only had 80 cents to my name and needed the money, so I signed it anyway. The moment I finished, I got an email from the company with an address under the text Come to this location tomorrow at 8:00am to start working with us. I didn't think much of it and went to sleep. When I woke up the next day, I put on a suit, wear my brand new Cologne, and started driving over to the location. But when I pulled into the parking lot, I knew something was off because there were no signs, no windows, and the location looked almost deserted. I figured I was probably just early, but the second I stepped inside the building, a super weird woman called Elizabeth came up to me, put me inside a creepy room, and said, you'll soon understand why we had you sign that death waiver. Was already regretting coming here, but it was too late. After a couple minutes passed by, she introduced me to this guy called Darren, who looked like he hadn't slept in like 20 years. Before I could even ask what the hell I was supposed to do, Darren pointed to a weird black box in the corner with a speaker and keyboard attached to it. That device can hear the dead. I immediately started laughing in his face and even glanced around for cameras, hoping all of this was just a
NA

I let my chronically late wife miss an event she was looking forward to by not rushing her because I wanted her to face consequences. My wife Jenna has this thing where she's always late. Not just fashionably late, but, like, 30 to 45 minutes late to everything. Dinner with friends, movies, work meetings, family gatherings. You name it, she's gonna be late for it. It drives me absolutely insane. The worst part is how she acts about it like it's no big deal. She'll roll her eyes when I tell her we need to leave, say, relax, babe, we have time when we absolutely don't, and then get mad at me for being stressed about it. Started telling her events start an hour earlier than they actually do, but she caught on and now just shows up even later. Last month was the breaking point. We were supposed to meet my parents for my dad's birthday dinner at this nice restaurant. I told her we needed to leave by 6:30 to get there on time. At 7:15, she's still doing her makeup, telling me to chill out because they'll wait for us. He showed up at 8:20. My parents had already ordered appetizers and were halfway through their main course. My dad looked hurt, my mom was pissed, and I wanted to disappear. But two weeks ago, something happened that Jenna had been talking about for months. Her favorite singer was doing this acoustic set at a tiny venue. Downtown. She'd been refreshing the ticket page for weeks trying to get seats, and somehow managed to snag two tickets when someone canceled last minute. She was beyond excited, posting about it on Instagram every day, telling everyone at work about it. The show was at 8 p m. On a Saturday. The venue was small.

Please, respectable name. Kyle jumped in, catching on. Very distinguished. What happened next was beautiful chaos. Janet immediately started googling how to talk your daughter in law out of terrible baby names. Emma was frantically texting me links to normal name lists. Kyle's dad kept muttering Nebuchadnezzar under his breath like he was trying to practice saying it. For the next three weeks I got calls every single day. Janet would call with alternative suggestions like Theodore or Michael. Emma sent me a 47 item list of actually cute names that aren't completely insane. Even Kyle's normally quiet aunt called to tell me about a nice couple she knew who named their daughter brunhilda, and she got teased terribly in school. The best part was watching them try to be supportive while obviously dying inside at the grocery store. Janet introduced me to her friend as my daughter in law. Who's expecting little Bartholomew or brinhilda? The poor woman didn't know what to say. Kyle was having the time of his life. He'd randomly bring up baby preparations like I wonder if they make monogrammed blankets with a G for Gaylord, just to watch his family squirm. Finally, at 38 weeks, we had the gender reveal party. Everyone was there with their fake smiles, probably praying we'd announce some last minute name change. We cut into the blue cake and Kyle goes well, looks like we're having a little Bartholomew. Janet actually gasped. Emma looked like she was about to Cry. Even the neighbors who'd been invited were giving each other these worried looks. That's when I started laughing. Like, couldn't stop laughing. Laughing. Kyle joined in, and pretty soon, we're both cracking

What's the most unforgivable thing you've ever seen someone do? There are lines in life you don't cross. And when you do, you don't just break the law. You break people. For me, that line was drawn the day my sister's case went to court. She had been through hell, hurt in a way I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy. She did everything right. Reported, gave statements, endured interviews, sat across from lawyers who asked her the most degrading questions you can imagine. She just wanted justice, um, recognition that what had been done to her mattered. I sat behind her in the courtroom, wearing the same suit I used for every hearing, notebook in hand. Not as a detective that day. Just a brother. Her attacker sat across the room, smug, relaxed, like he was at a casual lunch. Instead of facing charges for what he'd done. I kept staring at his hands, remembering how they'd shaken during questioning when I'd first confronted him off duty. That moment when you know someone's guilty, but they still think they can worm their way out. The trial wasn't long. Evidence lined up, witnesses were ready. The DA was confident. But when the judge walked in, I felt something I couldn't name. He wouldn't meet our eyes. Kept shuffling papers like he already hated being there. The DA made his opening statement clear and firm. Then came the defense, and it was pathetic. No alibi, no counterproof. Just character attacks and Cheap shots at my sister's credibility. But here's the thing. They didn't need a defense. Not when the judge himself was on their side. It started small. Objections overruled when they shouldn't have been. Evidence questioned that it had already been cleared for admissibility. The defense attorney practically smirking every time the judge leaned in their favor. Then the hammer blow. Halfway through testimony, my sister's voice trembling as she recounted the night everything changed, the judge actually cut her off. Said her words were too emotional to be considered reliable. He struck her testimony from the record. I felt my blood pressure spike. My fist clenched so tight, my nails dug into my palms. I wanted to shout.

Have you ever been asked to give up your seat in a restaurant? I just finished the worst shift of my life. 12 hours at the hospital, two cardiac arrests, one patient we couldn't save. My scrubs were still damp with sweat when I walked into Murphy's Diner at 2 in the morning. This place was my sanctuary after brutal shifts. Same booth in the corner, same hot chocolate with extra whipped cream. Same ritual of decompressing until my hands stopped shaking. The diner was dead quiet. Just me, the night cook, Larry, flipping eggs, one server named Beth reading a magazine, and two truckers arguing about gas prices up front. Perfect. I slid into my usual booth and ordered my drink. Twenty minutes later, this guy in an expensive suit walks in with his teenage daughter. Designer, everything shiny. Watch, the whole deal. The kind of guy who probably never worked a day shift in his life. I'm scrolling through my phone when I hear footsteps approaching. Excuse me, he says, standing right next to my table. You're sitting in our booth? I look up, confused. Sorry, this is our reserved booth. We need you to move. I glance around the empty diner. There's literally 12 other booths available. There's no reservation system here. It's a 24 hour diner. He waves at Beth behind the counter. Tell her we have this booth reserved. Poor Beth looks mortified. Sir, I just said you could ask if it was available. I Can't make customers leave. The guy turns back to me with this fake sympathetic expression. Look, can't you just be decent about this? It's my daughter's birthday. We've sat in this exact booth every year since her mother passed away. She died last spring from cancer. I pause. The girl is clutching a small balloon and looking uncomfortable. My heart softens for a second. Then he adds, besides, you've clearly been sitting here long enough. That did it. The fake concern

When did someone push you too far and you went all in? I own a small cafe in a college town. Not a chain, not fancy, just a cozy spot with good coffee, fresh pastries, and regulars I'll have their order started before they even reach the counter. Business was steady. Not booming, but enough to pay my barista as well and keep the lights on. Then out of nowhere, we started getting one star reviews. Not just any bad reviews. These were daily, always posted in the early morning, always detailed, and always personal. Coffee was lukewarm and the owner rolled her eyes when I asked for milk. The croissants are clearly frozen, not fresh baked. Owner talks too much to customers, slows down the line. None of it was true. We bake pastries at 4:00am every morning. My espresso machine hits 200 degrees like clockwork. And if I do talk to customers, it's because they're usually happy about it. I brushed off the first few, even replied politely offering to make things right. But they kept coming and they got nastier. She's rude, unprofessional, and probably microwaves the muffins. The weirdest part, the reviewer names were always different. The writing style was identical. Overly specific complaints, same sentence structure, same weird phrasing. Like coffee lacked robust notes. My rating dropped from 4.8 to 4.1 in under a month. In the cafe world, that's deadly. People really do skip over you for the place next door. If Your stars are lower. That's when I started digging. I created a fake Google account and responded to one of the fake reviews pretending to agree, just to see what would happen. Within an hour I got a private message from another customer account saying you should try Roast House instead. Much better coffee and service. This house, the other cafe three blocks away. My so called competition. I did a little late night social media stalking, scrolling through their tagged photos. That's when I saw him. Kevin the owner. Smug smile, designer apron. The kind of guy who brags about his ethically sourced beans while charging $7 for a latte. And right there in one of his own Facebook posts, the exact

When did a stranger think they could intimidate you and it blew up on them? I've been driving ride share for six years. I've seen everything. Couples breaking up mid ride, people trying to eat spaghetti in the backseat, even a guy who brought a goat. But nothing tops this one. It was a Friday night, 1:00am. A dangerous mix of drunk people, bad decisions, and too many. Just one more shots. I get a ping from a bar downtown. Five star passenger rating. Easy money, I think. I pull up and see him. Expensive suit, loosened tie, hair gel that could withstand a Hurricane. The kind of guy who calls waitresses sweetheart and tips with exposure. He stumbles toward my car, beer in hand. First red flag. Hey, buddy. I say, no open containers. He grins like I'm an adorable toddler. It's fine. I know people. Translation I'm about to be a pain in your ass. We get maybe three blocks before he starts making phone calls on speaker, loudly to people with names like Vince and Chad about closing the deal Monday. He keeps kicking the back of my seat like a bored five year old. Then out of nowhere, hey, driver, how much you make doing this? Like 40 grand. Pathetic. I keep it professional enough to pay the bills. That's when he leans forward, beer breath hot on my neck, and says, you're lucky to have me in your car. If I wanted to, I could Have your job by tomorrow. My company works with corporate for your app. Sure you do, champ. We're about two minutes from his address when he decides to really flex. You know what? I don't feel like paying tonight. Consider it a networking opportunity. You scratch my back, maybe I'll throw you some real work later. I smile in the rearview. You're saying you're refusing to pay for this ride? He laughs like it's the funniest thing he's ever heard. What are you gonna do, call the cops? I'll have them eating out of my hand before you can finish dialing. Here's the thing. I could call the cops, but I had something better. See, earlier that week, I driven his company's

When were you secretly proud of what your child did? I never thought I'd be that mom who cried at a Walmart checkout because her card got declined. But there I was last year, staring at a cart full of groceries I couldn't afford, while my 17 year old daughter, Anna, pretended not to notice the cashier's annoyed sigh. We'd been struggling since I lost my marketing job during the pandemic. Those unemployment checks barely covered rent, let alone everything else. Kept telling Anna everything would be fine, that I'd figure it out, but honestly, I was drowning. We started turning off heat in rooms we weren't using. I'd eat a sleeve of crackers for dinner and tell Anna I wasn't hungry. The pink envelope from the bank came on a Tuesday. Final notice. 30 days to pay or lose the house. I opened it in the kitchen and just collapsed right there on the linoleum floor, sobbing like a kid. I thought Anna was at school, but she'd come home early because she forgot her textbook. She found me there with that letter in my hands, hyperventilating. Mom, what's wrong? I tried to hide it, but she grabbed the paper and read it. Her face went completely white. How much do we owe? I couldn't even look at her. 43,000 back payments fee. He's everything. The next morning, Anna wasn't in her bed. Her backpack was gone, but her school clothes were still hanging in her closet. I called Her phone, like 20 times. Nothing. I was about to call the police when she finally texted back around noon. I'm fine at work. Talk tonight. Work. She worked part time at the grocery store on weekends. Maybe 15 hours total. What was she doing there on a Wednesday? When she came home that evening, she had this look on her face. Determined, but scared. Like she'd made a huge decision and wasn't sure if it was right. She sat me down at our kitchen

Have you seen someone create their own disaster? I run a barbecue food truck, and let me tell you, street vending is like the Wild West. No matter how good your brisket is, you're always one bad inspection away from losing everything. There's this one corner downtown that's gold. Heavy foot traffic, office workers at lunch, weekend festivals, you name it. The city only allows one truck there at a time, and you have to book it through their online permit system months in advance. It's first come, first served, and if you miss your day, too bad, you can't just swap in another truck without city approval. So I book my Friday slot three months ahead. I'm there early, set up smoker going, the works. Around 11 a m, another food truck rolls up. Bright neon paint job, giant Cartoon Taco plastered on the side. It's Taco titan, run by a guy named Vince. Vince jumps out in sunglasses and a leather jacket because apparently he's auditioning for Food Network's Douchebags in the wild. I'm taking this spot today. He says like it's a done deal. I laugh, thinking he's joking. Uh, no. I've got the permit. You can check with the city. He smirks. Oh, I don't need to check. See, your truck's a Dinosaur. I'm bringing in something fresh, Instagram worthy. People want tacos? Cool. I say you can give them tacos somewhere you're actually booked. Then he drops it. I've been parking here for Years without a permit. They never check. And you know what? If you call the city, I'll just tell them you invited me. Now, I'm a reasonable guy, but this is my living. My smoker takes four hours to get to 10. Moving is not an option. So I tell him straight, if you park here without a permit, that's on you. He parks anyway, right in front of my truck, like, literally blocking half my signage. At first I'm pissed, but then I remember something. Fridays are when the city inspector does his random rounds downtown. They check permits, sanitation and fire safety. And the inspector, he's a no BS kind.

What's the most out of touch thing a rich person has said to you? When I was 16, I lied on a job application and said I was 18 so I could clean these massive vacation houses in Aspen. My mom had died three months before from diabetes complications because we couldn't afford her insulin consistently. I was living with my aunt, who worked double shifts at a gas station just to keep our tiny apartment. These houses I cleaned were insane. Like bathrooms bigger than our entire place, with marble everything. And those fancy toilets that cost more than my aunt made in six months. I'd scrub these pristine kitchens that probably got used twice during their whole vacation. One Thursday afternoon, I was mopping the hallway in this ridiculous mansion when I heard screaming from upstairs. This 14 year old girl named Sienna was having a complete meltdown at her dad because he wouldn't buy her a second iPhone just for making TikToks. She already had the newest model, but apparently she needed a separate one for content creation. I tried to keep working, but then I heard her yell something that made my blood freeze. She screamed at her dad, if you're gonna be so annoying about money, why don't you just divorce mom and marry someone richer instead? I gripped that mop handle so tight, my knuckles went white. My mom had died on the same couch I slept on every night. We'd eaten ramen for Dinner probably 300 days that year. See, Sienna stormed out of the room and saw me standing there in the hallway. She rolled her eyes and said, uh, I hate when the help just stands around doing nothing. I wanted to say something, but I needed this job desperately, so I just kept mopping and pretended I didn't hear anything. Later, I was cleaning their kitchen when Sienna came in, talking to her friend on speaker phone. She was still ranting about the phone situation, saying stuff like, my dad is literally so cheap. I cried for, like, an hour, and he still

As a patient, what is the dumbest thing a doctor has ever recommended that you do? My daughter Rosie was six when she started limping around the house. At first I thought maybe she twisted her ankle at the playground or something. Kids are always falling and getting bruised up, right? But then she started crying about her legs hurting, especially at night. She'd wake me up at 2:00am, sobbing that her bones felt like they were on fire. I'd give her some children's Tylenol and rub her legs until she fell back asleep. This. This went on for about a week before I decided to take her to our pediatrician. Doctor Mitchell had been our family doctor for three years. He was this older guy who always seemed rushed, like he had somewhere more important to be. When I brought Rosie in, he barely looked at her for five minutes before giving his diagnosis. Well, she's carrying some extra weight, he said, looking at her chart. Kids her age should be running around more. Put her on a diet and try getting her outside more often. The leg pain is probably just from the extra strain. I stared at him. Sure, Rosie was a little chubby, but she was active. She rode her bike every day and loved playing at the park. But Doctor Mitchell was already writing something in her file and moving toward the door. But she's crying in pain every night, I said. She can barely Walk some mornings. He turned back with this annoyed look. Kids exaggerate. She's probably trying to get attention or avoid school. Just stick to the diet plan. I left feeling confused, but figured maybe he knew something I didn't. So I started packing healthier lunches for Rosie and taking her to the park every single day after school. But nothing changed. If anything, she got worse. Two weeks later, Rosie couldn't even get out of bed without help. Her little face was so pale, and she kept saying her legs felt heavy. I called Doctor Mitchell's office and managed to get another appointment. This time he seemed even more irritated when I walked in. He didn't

My brother got me kicked out. Now my he wants my house. When I was 16, my gaming obsessed brother Tyler convinced my parents I was taking up too much space in our cramped three bedroom apartment. He'd been complaining for months that he needed my room for his elaborate gaming setup. My parents sat me down one evening and basically said I had two weeks to find alternative living arrangements. The reasoning? I was almost 17, practically an adult, and Tyler needed space to pursue his passion in gaming. And they genuinely believed he was going to become the next big Twitch star. I was devastated, but had nowhere to go. My girlfriend Emma's parents noticed I've been spending more time at their house and eventually asked what was going on. When I explained the situation, her mom immediately said I could stay with them as long as I needed, no questions asked. Emma and I got serious fast. Living under the same roof will do that to a relationship. When we turned 19, I proposed with a ring. I'd saved six months for working overtime every weekend. Her parents were thrilled. They basically raised me for two years anyway and considered me their son. At 23, we finally had enough saved for a down payment on a small two bedroom house. Nothing fancy. We spent every weekend renovating, learning YouTube tutorials, making mistakes and fixing them. Meanwhile, Tyler was still living with my parents in his gaming paradise. He dropped out of community college after one semester, claiming his streaming career was about to take off and college was just holding him back. Three years later, he was still grinding away at maybe five viewers on a good day, sleeping until two PM, gaming until 4:00am, ordering Doordash.

A mall manager mocked my disabled brother in front of a crowd in the middle of his birthday trip. My younger brother, Ethan, turned 15 last Saturday. He's had cerebral palsy since birth, and while it affects his movement, it's never slowed down his sense of humor. The kid can roast me in Mario Kart and crack one liners that make my mom choke on her coffee. This year, all he wanted for his birthday was to go to the big shopping mall downtown. The one with the massive food court, arcade, and the store that sells those custom sneakers he's obsessed with. We've been planning it for weeks, saved up to buy him a pair. Mom took the day off work. Even the weather seemed like it was cooperating. We got there around noon, Ethan in his wheelchair with a brand new Marvel hoodie, beaming like it was Christmas morning. He spotted a balloon stand near the entrance, and the vendor tied one to the armrest of his chair. It floated above him like a little red exclamation Mark. We spent the first hour just browsing, Ethan pointing out things he wanted to totally buy when he's rich, me joking that he'd better remember his big brother when that happened. Eventually, we headed to the sneaker store. Ethan had been talking about this moment for months. He rolled right up to the display, ran his hand over the shoes, and looked at me like, is this real life? That's When it happened, out of nowhere, this guy in a mall manager badge strides over. Tall, late 40s, perfect hair, gel helmet. He stops a few feet from us and says loudly, sir, you can't just roll in here and block the displays. I thought he was joking. Ethan was completely in the clear, nowhere near blocking anyone. I said, he's just looking at the shoes. The manager gives me this fake customer service smile and says, I understand, but maybe you could take him somewhere more suitable. We don't want accidents. I felt my stomach drop. Ethan smile vanished. People around us turned to look. My mom froze midstep, gripping the handles of Ethan's chair. The manager laughed, an actual chuckle, and added, besides, this is a busy store. Someone might trip over him. Trip over him? Like my brother was an obstacle? Ethan's

My sister told me I was uninvited from our family reunion, so I took my barbecue and all the drinks with me. I was marinating ribs at 6:00am when Lexi texted me. You're uninvited. We don't want you there. No explanation, just a cold dismissal from the person who never lifted a finger for these reunions. For eight years, I've been the backbone of every family gathering. I brought the smoker, bought all the alcohol, coordinated everything. Lexi just showed up and took credit while I did the actual work. She waltzed in wearing some designer dress, pose for photos, and act like she organized everything while I was sweating over a hot grill. I stared at that text, hands covered in marinade, and typed back, fine, I'm taking my barbecue and drinks with me. An hour later, my phone explode. 15 missed calls from cousins, uncles, everyone panicking. Wait, you're not coming? What about the food? Lexi said you bailed on us. My voicemail was completely full. Text after text rolled in. Please tell me you're joking. The reunion won't be the same without your brisket. What happened? That's when I realized Lexi's fatal mistake. She never told them she uninvited me. She just announced I canceled and left them scrambling with no backup plan. Classic Lexi, creating problems and expecting everyone else to solve them. I texted my cousin Matthew. Lexi invited me, but you're welcome at my place. I've got everything we need. Matthew immediately called back. Absolutely furious. She did what? That's completely insane. I'm coming over and bringing everyone I can convince. Within minutes, half the family was choosing my backyard over Lexi's. Faster. Even the neighbors wanted in. When word spread about the impromptu cookout happening on my street, my phone kept buzzing with acceptances. Uncle Hank, on my way with the cornhole boards and my famous hot sauce. What's the scariest thing you've woken up to? One, when he was little, my younger son wouldn't try and wake you up if he needed something. He'd do that creepy thing kids do where they just stand there looking at you until you wake up. Well, I wake up at about 1:00am in a dark bedroom and see the black silhouette of a young kid standing right next to the bed. Golly, that's scary. Then he asked, hey, dad, Wanna play Rock Band 2? Waking up to my husband yelling, get out of my house. A man broke into my house and crawled in bed with me. Turns out he was in the house for a couple of hours. According to my door camera, my husband was asleep on the couch, came to bed and found the guy on the bed beside me asleep. Also, I accidentally left my door unlocked when I lived in this studio apartment in Philly. I woke up and it felt like someone was watching me. You know that feeling. Then I heard a shuffling noise and turn the lights on. There was a guy in a hoodie standing at the foot of my bed. I screamed. It was a young drunk dude that I literally had to push out. He seemed confused, but I'll never know what his intent was. I've never left my door unlocked since 3. Once I woke up to go to the bathroom, got up, smack something, slap me in The face. Turns out it was my entire right arm. Completely numb. Nearly scared the piss out of me and concerned me greatly afterwards. Has not happened since. 4. Back when I lived alone in an apartment, I used to wake up to just about anything. Never woke up more terrified than the night when I woke up to the sound of my toilet flushing. To this day, I can only assume that a ghost just couldn't hold it anymore. Five, I woke up and my dad's alarm clock was going off through the wall. He was a really light sleeper and he always turned it off immediately. It had been going off for several minutes and I think I knew before I got to his room that he was no longer with me. It was just so incredibly out of character for that alarm to be going off like that. He went in his sleep with a blanket still completely undisturbed. And I think I felt some small comfort at that, even though I was just a kid. 6, I once woke up to an earthquake at 4:00am. I lived in a house over the ocean on stilts, so my house was rocking like crazy. It was my first earthquake. And for some reason my brain first thought that someone was robbing me. I grabbed a machete and ran outside shirtless in my underwear. Neighbors next to me looked at me alarmed and started laughing. 7, my partner waking. Me up during a camping trip. He woke me to gather all our gear and our dogs into our truck ASAP. Lightning we had spotted six hours earlier in the day had sparked a wildfire. We got out as ash and sparks were falling around us. When we reached the top of the ridge surrounding our camp, we got out to look and watch the fire eat our entire campsite. We're so glad we called in the strike when we saw it. We met fire crews on our way out. The fire burned for like a week. One of the fires in Oregon in 2020, the Lakeview Paisley Fire 8, a bed bug infestation. I had had them for weeks and had no idea what they were. I would see one or two here or there and I'd just squash them, wonder what they were and move on. One morning, I woke up early and found quite a few of them on my bed. I started looking more closely and realised that the creases of the mattress were infested with them. Then I started to do some research, Learned that I had bed bugs, felt my soul leave my body, then began the process of getting rid of them. They're a psychological horror experience I wouldn't wish upon my worst enemy. Five years after the fact, and I still get paranoia attacks at a random speck in the sheets or mysterious red marks in the morning.

People who discovered a deal breaker partway through a date. What was the rest of the date like? One, first date from a dating app. We went for beverages at a hotel spot restaurant. When we were ordering the beverages, she said to the bartender, you can serve the restaurant menu here, right? I'll have the end. Proceeded to name the expensive dish she already knew by name. That was the there will be no second date red flag. The plan wasn't dinner, was a drink. Originally she had suggested an expensive restaurant, but I'd said let's just have a drink the first time, clearly just a foodie call. The I'm leaving now red flag was that she got on the phone and texted for a while, then said, my friends are coming to meet us. Let's order some more appetizers and a bottle. That was when I said the plan was some beverages to get to know each other, not be the wallet for your friends night out. I'll cover these beverages, have fun with your friends and left to pay my part of the Bill. Two, we matched on a dating app and he kept messaging me persistently, but he seemed like a nice guy. So he picked me up and took me to a decent sushi place. The actual dinner part went fine. Aside from him being very nervous and visibly sweating as he drove me home, he continually professed his love for me. By the time We got to my building. I was ready to book it as fast as possible into the entrance door which would lock behind me and he would be unable to enter without a key. Balked immediately. 3. An immediate red flag was that she told me she had no money and then she ordered the most expensive beverage on the list halfway through the date. She said she came from her ex boyfriend's house, but not to worry, they were no longer together. I finished my drink and excused myself to the bathroom. I tracked down our waitress and paid for our beverages. When I returned to the table, I told her I didn't think this was going to work out and left. Four, guy admitted to being technically homeless and crashing in a studio with two other guys. Told me he'd had 13 injuries that may have LED to memory loss. He didn't believe in key rings so he kept his keys on a rope, farted on a cat. I could go on. So much happened and all of it was unhinged. He got up to go to the bathroom and in a moment of inspiration and panic, I suddenly gained self awareness and realized I could leave. I threw money down on the bar top, made sympathetic eye contact with the bartender who had been watching the train wreck go down and then sprinted out of the restaurant. 5, she wanted to order lobster. I said, waiter, separate Bills, please. She glared at me, calling me broke while making the face. I ate my cheeseburger and fries and left her alone. Talk about spoiled. 6. We were having a very nice time, good chat, good company, etcetera. I looked over my shoulder to see the decor of the place we were in and she said, excuse me, I'm over here. She didn't like me not making eye contact all the time. If I looked away, she was insulted. The date ended and I drove away. 7, blind date, friend of a friend. He did not stop talking the entire time, didn't ask me one question. I just sat there mentally playing my favorite songs in my head until the Bill came. Because I'm a nice person and thought he might be nervous, I gave him another chance. The same thing happened over the phone. I fell asleep for 15 minutes and when I woke up, he was still talking. We did not meet up again. 8. She had never seen Star Wars. I'm not a fan. I don't even really like Star Wars. She brought up in conversation, complaining that her brother had become obsessed with the Star War. And that was it the whole rest of the date. Inside my head I asked myself, but how could she not know the name? Surely she's heard other people say it. Her brother has a lot of merch. She's read it many times. She doesn't have to care about It, but like, how is it even possible?

People who bought a house, what is the weirdest thing you have found left by the previous owner? One first time I took a hot shower in our new home, the steam covered the mirror only to reveal the phrase, hello, I see you in large finger drawn writing. It freaked me out for a second but made me laugh soon after that. It was such an inconspicuous yet obvious thing to leave for the new homeowner. Me. Two, wasn't a purchase, but I was showing a house to a couple and we couldn't believe the reported square footage. It looked like a nice 1,700 square foot house in a semi rural community, but the square footage on the listing said about 4,500. I was sure it was a typo. Turns out most of it was in the basement. Think Buffalo Bills basement. That just goes on and on with random rooms. The place was vacant. The lighting wasn't great. We got to a dead end room down there and turned on the lights and there was this porcelain doll just chilling in the middle of the room. Only thing left in the house. Husband yells, screw this, and we all run out. We ruled out that whole neighborhood as an option for obvious reasons. 3, $1,200 in cash above the door on the inside of the closet. I found it while painting. 4, we bought a house being foreclosed on. We gave him an extra month after closing in. 2000 to help with his move. Still had to have the sheriff come to remove him. Anywho, I was doing some clean up and remodeling before we moved in. The whole house was carpeted. When I started ripping it out, there was a giant blood stain that started in a downstairs spare bedroom and then trailed up to the master bath where there was another stain. His wife had left him. So I had to call the realtor to find out if anyone knew where she was. Turns out he had taken out a deer in the yard and gutted it in the house. What a hassle. Had to rip up and install new sub floors. My vegan ex wife was not thrilled. 5. The property my wife and I moved to three years ago had a bucket full of wrapped Dinosaur bones. Took them to our local museum where they confirm they are roughly 68 million years old. Hadrosaur. Pretty cool. 6. We bought the house from the CEO of the company which we franchise from. It was her childhood home where her mother lived until the day she passed. In true rich person fashion, they didn't care to clean out the house before selling it. They just told us we can do whatever we want with the old lady stuff that was there. We found a hidden box of spicy letters from the old lady to her secret partner spanning many years. That was fun to give to the CEO 7, my uncle was renovating the house that he bought for his chiropractic practice. And when he knocked down a wall to enlarge a room, a few dozen pill bottles fell to the floor. They were each filled with about 25 US silver dollars, which at the time were worth more like $6 in silver each. So it was about $5,000 in vintage coins. 8, that they wired a room by connecting the outlet with an extension cord inside the wall. 9, a diary of an American soldier in World War 2 South Pacific Theater found it above a door when remodeling 20+ years ago. My wife and I tried everything we could think of to find a descendant, but to no avail. Ten, a basement room that was fully decked out as a dungeon. Fake stone walls, a stocks like where you lock your head and hands in Old England. Candle scones on the walls, a metal barred cage in the corner from floor to ceiling. Oh, and the closet had a load of toys, some normal, some not so normal. 11, an entire tribe of raccoons living in the attic.

Which memorable Reddit post slash comment can you still not get over? One. The grandma who used coconut oil on her granddaughter who was extremely allergic and passed from it. As someone who works with toddlers, that story is a nightmare. Grandma nonchalantly caused the passing of her granddaughter. Not because she didn't know about the allergy, because she just didn't think it was a big deal. And in no time flat, a toddler is gone and two parents and two surviving siblings are forever traumatized. And grandma can't figure out why her daughter won't see her two. It wasn't as memorable or as big as most Reddit comments, but one has stuck with me. I forgot what the question was, but this guy commented that he was asked to bring like two gallons of milk to his girlfriend's family dinner. He thought, oh, they must really like milk. When he arrived, each family member had their own gallon of milk, and when dinner was served they all just started guzzling their own milk like animals. I need to try finding that. It was hilarious. 3 the one where the guy had an imaginary girlfriend, later wife, who was a giant cockroach, and his coworkers eventually found out that he had a whole fantasy life with his life size cockroach girlfriend slash wife. Four people seem to regularly post what Reddit post can't you get over? And I always drop in to say the pregnant woman whose husband and father In law decided she'd pass in labor and we're doing all the planning for that to happen. She never updated and I always wonder and worry a little. Wish I'd save the post. 5 the guy who was looking for legal advice because his landlord was sneaking in and leaving him notes while he was sleeping and someone in the comment section saved his life by realizing he was actually suffering carbon monoxide poisoning. Six the lady on ADA who unplugged her fridge to deep clean it while her husband had a box in there who told her to not open the box. I frequently wonder what was in the box. 7 the dude that bought a house with his GF and wasn't allowed upstairs. I want an update to this more than any unsolved mystery. 8 the guy who caught his wife cheating thanks to his Dyson fan epic. 9 the guy who Rick rolled Rick Astley.

And so can either of you stay overtime? We're short staff. I can't today. No, thank you. Whatever. It's the closing manager problem now, not mine. Looks like y'all need some help. I can take whoever's next over here. Thank you for helping. Yeah, no problem. Hey, how you doing? So you're closing tonight? Yep, today and tomorrow. Well, good luck. We've been short staffed all day, and we just got a couple more call outs. Oh, hey, would either of y'all mind staying overtime to help out with the rush? Yeah, I got you. Yeah, I can stay too. I appreciate it, guys. I thought y'all couldn't stay to help you. No, but Martin's helping us out, so we can help him.

My teacher thought I was cheating on a test, so she sent me to the ER. When I was in ninth grade, I got stuck with our school's worst teacher, who was infamous for trying to make a Muslim girl take off her headwear to prove she wasn't wearing headphones in class. There were a lot of students who got away with cheating by wearing headphones during tests, so she was constantly checking. Since then, she didn't do anything too bad until we had to take our final exam at the end of the year, and she stood up to walk around the room. It was really hot that day, so I wore a lighter shirt. I also happened to have type 1 diabetes, so you could see my insulin pump. That day, my blood sugar was low, so I turned my pump on and walked into class. We were almost done taking the test, and she stood up to walk around the room. I was honestly focused on just passing until I heard her walk straight up behind me. In that moment, two things happened. She grabbed my paper off my desk and told me I failed, and I felt her grab the pump on my waist. I just sat there in shock as she walked away and had no idea what had just happened. However, it wasn't until I noticed she was holding Scissors that it clicked what she had just done. She seen the wire hanging off My waist and assumed I had headphones in. When I looked down, the tube was cut. After a few seconds, my pump started beeping very loudly and everyone started looking at me. A few people sitting around me saw what happened and were in shock. She came over and when she realized what she did, I watched her face turn pale. She had messed up big time and had no idea what to do, and neither did I. She told me to go to the nurse, and on the way there, I started getting. I made it there. Could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. Entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything and she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in real time. Then as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang, and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving. There was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted, but then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway, and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help! He has a gun! And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows, and everyone started flooding out the back door. I move, and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could, and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there with our Hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out, and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us. And we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife, Stephanie, waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said. And I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked? Because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping? We date each other's spouses. She said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered. Room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said, let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something. But then I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. That should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. Put on this red Dress I've never seen before, that she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul never. She started, then stopped at dinner. She pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly, for months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand before. What? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name and she turned it face down. Immediately I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How was Cassie? Good. How was Paul? Then she started telling me everything they did, the hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you wanna know? No, her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down out of Nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner she had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked. And her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons, that's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents'house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom.

You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like, no big fall out, no drama. Just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened. Like, what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part. I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this. Or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't. Cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. Yeah. I could reach out. I could say something. Deep down, I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it. Pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them, I really wanted to stay.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parent decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to Enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. Their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of Zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.

People who work in HR, what's the wildest thing you've discovered that LED to a firing? Two women in our accounting department got pregnant at almost the exact same time. Jessica found out first and was super excited, showing everyone her ultrasound photos and talking about baby names during lunch breaks. Three weeks later, Amber announced she was also pregnant, due just two weeks after Jessica. Everyone was thrilled. The whole office was buzzing about having two babies so close together. Both women submitted their maternity leave paperwork right away, since we needed time to arrange coverage for their positions. Jessica went on leave first. When her daughter was born, everything seemed normal. Then Amber went into labour early, about a week before her scheduled leave was supposed to start. That's when things got weird. Our payroll system flagged an error. When I tried to process Amber's leave, it said someone had already filed maternity leave under her name and Social Security number. I figured it was just a computer glitch, so I called our IT department. They pulled up the records and found something impossible. According to our system, Amber had already been on maternity leave for three weeks. But she'd been working the whole time. She was literally at her desk yesterday. I started digging deeper and found the original leave request filed under Amber's name. It had her Social Security number, her employee ID, everything. But the submission date was from a month ago, right when Jessica Had filed hers. Something was seriously wrong here. I pulled the security footage from the day the duplicate paperwork was submitted. At 6:47 p m, after most people had left, Jessica was sitting at Amber's desk, using her computer. She spent 43 minutes there printing documents and filling out forms. But it got worse. Way worse.

My boyfriend saw my Venmo and asked, why are you getting paid $500 weekly by someone called Sugar Daddy? I nearly choked on my cereal because that was not a conversation I wanted to have at 8:00am on a Tuesday. It's not what it looks like, I said quickly. But Jake was already scrolling through my transaction history with his eyebrows raised. Really? Because it looks like you're getting paid every Friday for the past three months by someone whose contact name is literally Sugar daddy Mike with money bag emojis. He turned his phone toward me showing the evidence. Are you seriously doing that kind of work? Without telling me, I grabbed my phone back, my face burning red. Jake, I swear to God it's not what you think. Mike is my boss at the pet sitting company. He stared at me like I'd grown a third leg. Your boss pays you through Venmo and you call him Sugar Daddy Mike? I realized how absolutely insane this sounded, but it was the truth. The company payroll system has been broken for months. Mike pays all the employees through Venmo. And I saved his contact as Sugar Daddy Mike as a joke because he's always buying us coffee and treats for the dogs. Jake was not buying this explanation at all. That's the most ridiculous cover story I've ever heard. Look, I'll prove it. I called Mike right there in our kitchen. He answered on the second ring with his Usual cheerful voice. Hey, and you're not scheduled until this afternoon. Everything okay? I put him on speaker. Mike, my boyfriend thinks we're having some kind of inappropriate relationship because of how you pay us and how your name shows up in my phone. Mike burst out laughing. Oh, no, not again. This happened with my daughter's boyfriend last month. He thought she was cheating on him with her sugar daddy Mike. He explained to Jake that his payroll company had been hacked six months ago, so he'd been paying everyone through cash apps. Jake still looked skeptical. But why Sugar Daddy Mike? Mike laughed even harder. Because I spoil my employees and the pets rotten. Free coffee every day, premium dog treats, bonuses for good work. The girls started calling me Sugar Daddy Mike because I'm always buying supplies and treating them like family. He invited Jake to come by the office to meet the team. You can meet the other four dog walkers who probably also have me saved as Sugar Daddy Mike in their phones. I could see Jake starting to believe the story, but he was still embarrassed about jumping to conclusion. This is why you should have just told me you had a job, he muttered. After we hung up with Mike, Jake apologized profusely. I should have just asked you directly instead of making assumptions. But then he got curious about other things. Wait, if you're only making $250 twice a month, how are You paying for all those expensive dinners you've getting delivered? My stomach dropped because I've been hoping he wouldn't notice my Doordash habit. That's a different situation, I said, trying to change the subject. But Jake was already connecting dots. Please tell me you're not actually doing sugar daddy stuff on the side to pay for food. I just waved it off and tried to ignore him for the rest of the day. The next day, I brought Jake to the pet sitting office to meet Mike and prove my story. He was exactly what you'd expect, 50 something guy in dog hair covered clothes who immediately offered us both coffee and dog treats to sample. See, he said to Jake, total sugar daddy behaviour but completely innocent. The other employees confirmed that they all had similar contact names for Mike and that he was basically the most generous boss ever. Last month he paid for my dog's vet Bill when I couldn't afford it, one co worker said. Jake felt terrible for assuming the worst and bought lunch for the whole pet sitting crew as an apology. I watched too much true crime, he explained to Mike. When I I saw those payments, my mind immediately went to the darkest possibility. Mike laughed it off and said it happened more often than you'd think. My wife gets suspicious, looks at the bank when she deposits checks made out to Sugar Daddy, Mike's Pet Care. That night, Jake finally relaxed. Convinced everything was fine. But when I checked my phone before bed, another 500 dollar transfer came in. The message read, good job. He bought every word.
NA

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque. Not here on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare, bro. Rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught smallpox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got a I rockets to Mars and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First, it was Covid tearing everything apart. Then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20 and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude, maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, figured why not? My little sister Mia is 15 and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for like an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. And Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I found my Sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what?
NA

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

We both jumped up and ran upstairs, and I found my Sister standing in her doorway, crying, like, full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway. King all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what

How do I tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real? It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said, I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her coworker, Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back, Easter brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball. Scores. My dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated, remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, would grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept filling glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting Back or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.
