The whole car ride home, I kept steal blinking glances at him wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, that she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever. You know, that message hit me like a truck. I realized he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead, Of texting back or giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favorite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over at the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.

My wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her? After three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at two a m, reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends, authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week, she said maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday, she noticed. You're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes. Obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet. The twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny, because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal. Next one who spends weekends bar hopping, crying about how all men are trash. Crystal. Hey. My wife's been telling me about Your amazing single life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth with you guys? Talk about through the phone? Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out? But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal backpedal. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said, dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting? Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at 35. Debbie, great news. My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in? I. There's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale, watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard, but they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can Go to yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine. Listening to you repeat your poison every night. Or yours. Because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love. You got it. The irony. Her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed too hard. Janet called later, begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Don't change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Sky, Taylor kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her moods. Things. Year 1 was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball in our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I've forgotten how To enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor, I only helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught sky to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after Three years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living.

My dad treated us like crap until his boss had dinner at our house. For 17 years, I lived with two different fathers. The perfect employee who preached about his perfect marriage and strong kids, and the man who made mom sob herself to sleep for buying the wrong coffee brand. Mom Learned to time grocery shopping before his Thursday bowling league when he'd be rushed. Once she forgot, dad discovered generic pasta instead of name brand. You're too stupid to even shop, right? No wonder you never amounted to anything. He made her return every item while he watched, then quizzed her on prices to prove she was wasting his money. She cried in the car afterward. That weekend's company barbecue. I do the shopping because the wife gets overwhelmed by choices. His co workers laughed at how understanding he was. My brother walked past Dad's home office during a virtual meet. Invisible for just two seconds, dad kept smiling, discussing collaborative workspace culture. The second he clicked leave meeting, he cornered my brother. You made me look like I can't control my own house. The belt came out. Two weeks of complete silence followed. My brother stopped eating, stopped talking at school. Teachers thought he was just shy. I saved money from my part time job for college application fees, knowing he'd never support it. He found them anyway. You think you're better than me? He burned them in the kitchen sink while I watched. Later, his boss Asked about my plans. She's applying everywhere. We stay up late working on essays together. I nodded and smiled, knowing I'd missed every deadline. Two fathers. Only we knew which one was real. Then my dad announced, the CEO is coming to dinner on Saturday. After ten years grinding for senior VP, a 1 hundred thousand dollar promotion, it came down to this. The CEO was famous for his values based leadership. He'd fired executives for screaming at waitstaff. I passed over vps for bad parenting in public. Now he wanted to see Dad's home life personally. With a three hour dinner. One mistake, dad hissed, and I'll make you regret it forever. But dad had never maintained his perfect act at home for more than 20 minutes. Phone calls, easy, quick. Doorway chats, no problem. But three hours in his kingdom, where he trained us to fear him. That's never happened before. Watched Mom's hands shake, my brother shrink into his chair. For 17 years, home was where dad dropped his mask. Saturday, he'd have to keep it on for three whole hours. There was no way, right? We all prepared like our lives depended on it. Practiced conversations, rehearsed dinner etiquette. Cleaned until the house looked like a magazine spread. I helped mom cover the bags under her eyes. My brother practiced speaking in full sentences. Again. Dad was a wreck. Pretending to be calm. He'd bark orders, catch himself, force a smile. Remember, we're a happy family. He'd say through gritted teeth, the vein in his forehead pulsing. Saturday arrived and the doorbell rang. Showtime, Dad whispered, transforming into the man his co workers knew. A warm smile with a firm handshake. Welcome to our home. The first hour was perfect. Dad told charming stories. We laughed at the right moments. Mom served flawlessly. But I watched dad carefully. Saw his jaw clench when my brother took too long answering a question. I noticed his knuckles whitening when mom laughed too loudly at the CEO's joke. I watched that familiar vein start to pulse. By hour, two cracks appeared. His smile became strained, his laugh forced. He was gripping his wine glass so tight, I thought it might shatter. This was the longest he'd ever had to pretend in his own home. And it was killing him. I didn't have to do anything. I just had to wait. Then it happened. During dessert, mom served the sea

Every school has that annoying ass girl group who thinks they're the shit and every boy likes them. Like bro, they're always looking for attention. Like, Omg, everyone is staring at us. What the fuck? And then my fuck ass friends have the audacity to say, you like her, don't you? Like what? No, they're all fucking chopped and built like oversized vending machine friends every week like it's a fucking Netflix series. New season, new guy. Make fun of other people's looks. But then they take pictures and scribble out the spots on their face like, bro, you're just a fucking hypocrite. The worst part is when the girl everyone thinks I like starts playing along with it. We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me that someone was infected with the plague in 2025? Like, how do you even let that happen? This isn't a cold. This isn't allergies. This is the plague. That's the kind of word you should only read in a museum plaque, not here, on a Tuesday morning news update. And the way the news says it is always so casual. A rare case of the plague was reported this week. Rare? Bro, rare should mean never again. That's not supposed to be in circulation. That's like saying, oh, yeah, someone caught small pox on their lunch break. They'll hit you with, don't worry, it's treatable now. Okay, cool. But imagine being the one person who goes to urgent care with a fever, and the doctor walks in wearing a bird mask and carrying a bag of leeches. That's not medical attention. That's a medieval horror show. Like, think about how cooked we are if the plague can just pop back up. We've got A I. Rockets to Mars, and somehow we're still fighting the same disease that wiped out half of Europe. That's not progress. That's a rerun. Every headline feels less like news and more like a countdown. First it was COVID tearing everything apart, then wildfires turning skies orange. Now the plague shows up. Tell me this doesn't feel like end credits.

What's your perfect example of play stupid games, win stupid prizes? My high school made all the boys holding their pee because someone wrote hi on the wall in Sharpie. Monday morning, we all showed up to find a sign taped to the boys bathroom door, closed until further notice due to vandalism. The girls bathroom was still open, of course, but our school only had one bathroom for boys in the entire building because it was an old school built in the 60s when they apparently thought teenage boys never needed to pee. Principal Carpenter made an announcement during 1st period, due to the disrespectful graffiti found in the boys restroom, this facility will remain locked until someone comes forward with information about who did it. The entire male population of our high school groaned at the same time. The crazy part was what the graffiti actually said. My friend Peyton had seen it Friday before they locked everything up. Someone had written hi in tiny letters on the bathroom stall. Not a curse word, not a drawing, just hi, I in black Sharpie about the size of a quarter. By lunch, the situation was getting desperate. Guys were asking teachers for hall passes to go to the nurse's office just to use that bathroom. But the school nurse caught on quick and started turning people away unless they were actually sick. Some guys tried using the staff bathroom but got detention for that. A few desperate souls walked To the gas station across the street during lunch. But security started watching for that, too. We tried talking to Principal Carpenter. Reasonably group of five guys went to his office to explain that punishing 300 boys for one tiny word was insane. He sat behind his big desk with his arms crossed. Actions have consequences. When the vandal comes forward, everyone gets bathroom privileges back. By Wednesday, things were getting bad. Guys were dehydrated from not drinking water all day. The basketball team couldn't practice properly because half the players were holding it in. Parents started calling to complain. The carpenter wouldn't budge. He sent out an email saying this was a lesson in collective responsibility. That's when Dean Patterson had his brilliant idea. He was this quiet kid.

His voice cracks or he stumbles over words. When talking to you, he finds small excuses to be near you. He shows up where you are more often than coincidence allows. He remembers the little things. Comment I hate when and let your keyboard finish the sentence. Even if he doesn't talk much, he notices details about you, like your favourite snack, something you said weeks ago. He pays attention in ways others might overlook. He interacts differently with you than with others. He may be loud and confident with friends, but quiet around you. He engages online more than in person. He texts, comments, or likes your posts, but is quieter face to face. He's more relaxed when there's no direct eye contact. Before the last fact. Please like the video and follow or you might never see me again. His friends know something. They tease him when you're around. They may drop hints or act differently toward you because they know how he Feels

Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the plate.

My wife demanded we swap partners with her best friend, so I went along with it. My wife Stephanie, waited until we were eating dessert at Cassie and Paul's house to drop this on me. We should swap partners every Thursday, she said, and I literally watched her put her hand on Paul's thigh under the table. I saw it. Cassie saw it, too, and her face went blank. What? I asked because I honestly thought I heard her wrong. Partner swapping. We date each other's spouses. Said it like she was talking about switching cars for the weekend. Paul kept staring at his plate and wouldn't make eye contact with me. It's already decided, Stephanie said. Thursday nights, you take Cassie out, Paul takes me. I felt my chest get tight. When did they decide this without me? This is insane, I told her. Then she leaned in close and whispered, room 2:37 last Tuesday when you were at work. My whole body went numb. She was telling me she'd already cheated and now wanted my permission to keep doing it. So are you in or not? She asked louder. I looked at Cassie, and she was crying without making any sound. Fine, I said. Let's swap partners. Stephanie smiled like she just won something, but. And I noticed Cassie had stopped crying completely. That should have told me something right there. When the first date night came around, Stephanie spent forever getting ready. She put on this red Dress I'd never seen before that she'd been hiding in our closet. Paul's car was already running in our driveway when I left. I brought Cassie white roses because I remembered she mentioned liking them once. Her hands shook when she took them. Paul? Never. She started, then stopped. At dinner. She pushed her food around and barely ate anything. You okay? I asked. Paul's been different, she said quietly. For months, even before. Then she stopped talking again. I reached over and touched her hand. Before what? Nothing. Forget I said anything. But then her phone lit up with Stephanie's name, and she turned it face down immediately. When I got home that night, Stephanie was already there. Her hair was all messed up and her lipstick was smeared on the wrong side of her mouth. How is Cassie? Good. It was Paul. Then she started telling me everything they did. The hotel room, the balcony, what they did against the wall. She kept getting louder with each detail. Stop, I told her. Why? Don't you wanna know? No. Her face got all twisted up. Well, I'm telling you anyway. She kept going with more details while I pulled out my phone and texted Cassie, thank you for a lovely evening. Stephanie saw my screen and threw her wine glass at the wall. It shattered everywhere, and I just stood there looking at her. The next week, I had to pick Cassie up because her car broke down. Out Of nowhere. Paul was supposed to drive me, she said, looking confused. I forgot at dinner. She had way too much wine. Can I tell you something? She asked, and her eyes looked glassy. Tuesday afternoons. That's when it started. My heart started racing. What started? She covered her mouth with her hand. Nothing. Forget it. But Tuesday was when Stephanie had mentioned the hotel and we both knew what she meant. Then we had to go to Stephanie's parents house for dinner. Stephanie showed up late and I could smell Paul's Cologne all over her clothes. Her mom noticed it right away and her face changed. Is that men's Cologne? The whole table went quiet. We're sharing partners with Cassie and Paul, I said. Every week. Her dad dropped his fork and it made this loud sound. Sharing? Taking turns dating each other's spouses. Stephanie's idea. Her mom stood up from the table in my house, she said, and her voice was shaking. Stephanie tried to explain, but everyone had already smelled the Cologne and knew what was happening. That night Cassie called me. I know about Tuesday afternoons. I felt sick to my stomach about them. I followed Paul once four months ago to the hotel. She sounded drunk. I saw everything. By week five, everything fell apart. It was Cassie's birthday and I threw her a surprise party, made a video of all her artwork and gave the speech about how talented and kind she was. Paul Forgot it was her birthday completely. I watched Stephanie watch Cassie cry happy tears and hold on to me like she didn't want to let go. That night, Stephanie came home from Paul's and started telling me what they did in graphic detail again. Stop! I don't want to hear it. She got mad. But I'm telling you everything. I didn't ask. Then she demanded to know what Cassie and I did together.
NA
NA

Wife confessed during a family dinner that she always wished she married my best friend. So I packed my things and left, but now she's begging me to come back. Last Sunday at my in law's house for their 30th anniversary dinner, everything seemed perfect. My wife Emma was helping her mom arrange flowers while I watched the game with her dad. My buddy Josh was there, too. He's been like family since college, always invited to everything. The whole extended family was there, maybe 20 people total. Emma's cousins, her weird Uncle Dave who likes vintage spoons. Her grandmother, who still asks when we're having kids even though we've been trying for three years. After dinner, her Aunt Linda starts this thing where everyone shares their sliding door moments. Those what if scenarios that keep you up at night. Everyone's going around the table sharing cute stories. Her cousin Sarah talks about almost moving to Japan to teach English. Uncle Dave mentions nearly buying Bitcoin in 2,010. Her brother Tom jokes about almost joining the military instead of becoming an accountant. Normal, harmless stuff that gets people thinking. Then it's Emma's turn. She's had a few glasses of wine, and she gets this dreamy, distant look in her eyes, like she's somewhere else entirely. Honestly, she says, looking directly at Josh across the table, I sometimes think I should have dated Josh instead of Mark back in college. We just click so naturally, you know, the entire table goes Dead silent. Her dad literally chokes on his coffee and starts coughing violently. Her mom drops her fork with a loud clatter. Her grandmother's mouth falls open. I'm sitting right there like a complete idiot, watching my wife of eight years fantasize about my best friend in front of our entire family. Josh's face goes bright red. He starts stammering something about how that's not appropriate. But Emma just keeps going like she's in some kind of trance. I mean, we have so much more in common than Mark and I. I do. Josh actually listens when I talk about my art projects. He gets my sense of humor. He remembers little things I say. Sometimes I wonder if I settled too quickly. That last part hit like a freight train. Settled? After eight years of marriage, two miscarriages, buying our first house together, and me working overtime to pay for her art supplies, I settled. I excused myself to the bathroom. But really, I just sat in my car for 20 minutes trying to process what had just happened. My hands were shaking. I called my brother Mike, but couldn't even form words to explain. When I came back inside, everyone was pretending nothing happened, making awkward small talk.
NA

How did you scam the scammer? Last Tuesday, I was making lunch for my kids when my phone rang. Unknown number, but I picked up anyway. Big mistake, right? This guy with a thick accent starts telling me he's from the IRS and I owe $4,200 in back taxes. As if I don't pay immediately with gift cards, the police will arrest me within an hour. Now, here's the thing. I literally just got my tax refund two weeks ago. My accountant, Beth, handled everything perfectly and I even got money back. So I knew this dude was full of it. But instead of hanging up, something clicked in my brain. My neighbour, Missus Kim, had fallen for this exact scam last month and lost $800. Time for payback. I started crying into the phone, oh, no, I can't go to jail. My kids need me. The scammer ate it up. He told me to go to target and buy iTunes gift cards worth $2,000 as a first payment. I said I needed an hour to get the money together. First, I called my cousin, Jake, who's a cop, told him what was happening and he said to keep the guy on the line as long as possible. Then I started my revenge tour. I called the scammer back an hour later sobbing. I'm at target, but I'm so confused. Which gift cards do I buy? He walked me through it step by step. I pretended to be this helpless Single mom who didn't understand technology. Sorry, can you repeat that? My hands are shaking so bad. For the next 20 minutes, I wandered around target asking him questions. Do I need the physical cards or the digital ones? The cashier is asking for ID is that normal? Sorry, my 4 year old is having a meltdown in the cart. Finally, I told him I had the cards. He was so excited, probably thinking about his commission. I read him the first number. Okay, it starts with 5. Wait, is that a 5?
NA

What's your most bitter sweet childhood memory? When I was 8, my cousin Tiffany came to live with us for six months while her parents sorted out their divorce. I'd always wanted a sister and suddenly having a 12 year old girl in the house who knew about makeup and had actual opinions about music seems like winning the lottery. My mom set up the guest room for her with new curtains and cleared out half the closet. Dad built an extra shelf for her books. My little brother Sean, who was only 5 then, followed her everywhere until she taught him a secret handshake that made him feel special. The first weekend Tiffany was with us, she suggested we build a time capsule. I collected items all week. I contributed my favorite marble. Sean added a plastic Dinosaur. Mom put in a recipe card and dad included a baseball card. Tiffany added something wrapped in tissue paper that she wouldn't show anyone. This stays sealed until exactly 10 years from now, Tiffany said. As we buried it under the old maple tree in the backyard. We marked the spot with rocks arranged in a circle. Every Sunday became capsule checking day, where we'd go out to make sure the rocks hadn't been disturbed. Sometimes Tiffany would press her ear to the ground and claim she could hear our treasures talking to each other. Sean believed her completely. I pretended to believe but secretly knew better. Still, I played along. In Month 4, our neighbors Adrian and Yasmin invited us to their daughter Molly's birthday party. Molly was Tiffany's age and they become friends at school. The day before the party, I overheard mom on the phone. I know it's difficult, but you need to make a decision soon, mom said. She's doing well here. She asks about you every day. That night, Tiffany taught me to braid my hair. Her fingers worked quickly and I sat perfectly still, afraid any movement might make her stop. When she finished, she took a picture with her disposable camera. This is how I'll remember you, she said. At Molly's party, the adults gathered in the kitchen while us kids played games in the basement. I noticed Tiffany kept checking the stairs. When Molly's mom called everyone up for cake, Tiffany pulled me aside. I have to tell you something, she whispered. I'm going back home next week. The cake tasted like nothing. After that, I watched Tiffany laugh with Molly and the other older girls. She seemed happy, not like someone about to leave everything behind. On her last night with us, we had pizza, Tiffany's favorite, with extra cheese. Dad made ice cream sundaes and mom gave Tiffany a necklace with a tiny silver heart. Sean cried when he found out she was leaving and refused to do their secret handshake. It won't be special anymore if we do it when I'm leaving, Tiffany explained after Sean went to bed. Tiffany And I sat on the porch swing. I wanted to ask her why she had to go, why she couldn't just stay with us forever. But instead, I asked about the time capsule. What did you put in there that you wouldn't show us? A letter to you, she said, about why I really came to stay here. The next morning, her dad picked her up in a car I'd never seen before. Mom hugged him for a long time. Tiffany hugged each of us. But when she got to me, she whispered, remember 10 years? We got two postcards from her that summer, then Christmas cards for a few years, then nothing. Mom said, people get busy. Dad said, that's just how life works sometimes. When I was 13, Sean wanted to dig up the time capsule early. I wouldn't let him. I promised Tiffany we'd wait the full 10 years. Last month marked exactly 10 years. I came home from college for the weekend and went straight to the maple tree. The rocks were gone. Landscapers had redone the yard years ago. I dug where I thought the capsule should be. Nothing. I tried another spot. Nothing again. I was about to give up when my shovel hit something.
NA

Have you ever became a restaurant regular and didn't even realise it? So I'm going through this absolutely soul crushing breakup with my boyfriend of three years. You know, the kind where you can't eat, can't sleep and your friends are tired of hearing about it. I start going to this 24 hour diner at like 2:00am because I literally cannot sleep. It's one of those old school places with cracked vinyl boobs and fluorescent lights that make everyone look dead. First night I order coffee and pancakes and just sit there scrolling through my ex's Instagram like the masochist I am. The waitress, this woman in her 50s with kind eyes just keeps refilling my coffee without saying anything. Second night, same thing. Third night she finally asks, rough patch, honey? I nod and try not to cry into my syrup. By the end of week two, I'm there every single night at exactly 2:00am. Same booth, same order, same pathetic scrolling routine. That's when she sits down across from me. Alright, sweetie, you've been here 14 nights straight. Crying into pancakes. What's his name? And I just break. I tell her everything, how he cheated, how he moved in with her immediately, how all our mutual friends picked sides. She listens to every word while bringing me free pie. The next night she introduces me to the cook, Hank. This is pancake girl. She's having serious boy troubles. Hank, this massive guy with tattoo sleeves, looks at me And goes, what kind of idiot breaks a heart like that? Then he makes me these incredible chocolate chip pancakes shaped like a heart. Soon the whole night shift knows my business. There's Madison, the other waitress who gives me brutal but honest dating advice. Cameron, the dishwasher who barely speaks English but always pats my shoulder and says, no cry. Mija. Even the manager, Frederick, starts checking on me. They give me a nickname, Pancake Girl. There's actually a coffee mug behind the counter with PG written on it and Sharpie. That's mine. Now. One night I'm telling Madison about how my ex posted vacation photos with his new girlfriend and she gets this evil smile. Honey, you know what tonight's pancakes are on the house. Hank's making you the forget that loser special. It's a stack of pancakes with you deserve better written in whipped cream. Week 3, they start giving me relationship homework. Tomorrow, tomorrow night you're deleting his number, says Madison. We'll watch you do it. Week 4, they make me change my relationship status on Facebook. Right there at the table, more cheering. By week 5, they're basically running a late night therapy session. Other customers start joining our conversation. There's this trucker named Malik who shares his divorce story. A nurse coming off her shift who talks about her toxic ex. We become this weird little support group. Week 6, guess who walks in at 2:00am with his new girlfriend? My ex of all The diners in the city. He picks mine. I'm frozen. They're looking around for a table. I'm about to have a panic attack when Madison appears like some kind of guardian angel.

Why do kids try so hard in gym class? Like, bro, it's second period, you're gonna smell like wet donkey balls all day. And the gym teachers don't help. They're like, give me your best effort, sir. This is not the Olympics. It's Wednesday, 9:30 a. M. And we're playing kickball. Nobody should be breathing that hard before lunch. Then you see kids acting like dodgeball decides their whole future, sliding on the floor, dripping sweat, shirts sticking to them like duct tape. All of this just to go sit in science class leaking onto the desk. And now the whole row smells cooked. You're stuck breathing in wet donkey balls in class because someone thought he was LeBron James at 9:00am. Hard to focus on the math problems in front of me when there's a stench like that behind me. The air is actually unlivable. Every class after feels like punishment. Follow for more rants.
NA
NA

Bro, 2,025 just got way more cooked because I just realized today is September 5th. 2,025 which officially means we're 67.67% through the year. And listen, this is where shit gets weird. Mango has six letters, mustard has 7. 6 + 7 = 13. Now Kendrick Lamar. That's 13 letters. And the 13th letter in the alphabet is M. You know what M stands for? Massive. But wait. And if that wasn't enough, low taper fade has 12 letters. Now add that up. 13 + 12 = 25. What year are we in? The big 25? This is massive news for the unemployed.

Bro, TikTok got me side eyeing my own selfies. Now they wrote out this feature where you take a picture and TikTok assigns you a song that matches your vibe. Cute idea, right? No, this app is a savage emotional assassin. So I tested it. Took a pic of me holding my smoothie. Healthy, glowing, feeling. Great. TikTok said unwell by Matchbox 20. Hello, I'm drinking spinach, not crying in the club. Then I tested my roommate. He took a photo of his car keys. TikTok gave him Boulevard of broken dreams. Bro just wanted to go to Walgreens. Now he's in an existential spiral over his 2,012 Civic. Next, I snapped a pic of my bed. Just my bed. No messy sheets, no emotional context. TikTok gave me lonely by Akon. Now I'm hugging my pillow like it's a person. Why am I being attacked? It's not random. It's personal. This app isn't just matching vibes. It's dragging your soul through emotional Spotify. Then my friend uploaded her Starbucks. TikTok hit her with Material Girl. She was like, honestly, fair? It's the only one that didn't feel like a punch in the chest. At this point, I'm convinced TikTok ain't just an app. It's an AI therapist with Wi-Fi and zero chill. Go try it. Snap a pic. But be warned, TikTok might know your deepest fears, and it will expose them with a banger.

What happened when my mom demanded 24 7 access to my phone? When I turned 15, my mom went from strict to straight up paranoid. One night after dinner, she plopped down next to me with this weird smile and said she was installing a family safety app on my phone. I watched her tap away, giving herself access to everything. My location, photos, texts, even my drafts on social media. It's just to keep you safe, honey, she said, handing my phone back like nothing had changed. But everything had changed. It felt like having a stalker who lived in my house. At first I tried to be cool about it. Maybe it would calm her down, right? Wrong. Things got insane fast. She text me in the middle of conversations asking who I was with. Comment on memes I haven't even posted yet because she was reading my drafts. The worst part? She started replying to my friends pretending to be me. My buddy Jake texted asking if I wanted to hang out, and my mom replied, sure. Sure thing, buddy! With way too many exclamation points. Jake called me laughing, asking why I was texting like a soccer mom. I had no idea what he meant until I checked my messages. Then came the day that broke me. I was in history class when Mrs. Wilson pulled me aside. Looked uncomfortable as hell. Liam, your mother called the school. She's concerned about some message you sent about Me. My stomach dropped. I knew exactly what she meant. I texted my best friend Kyle the night before, joking about how our history teacher's haircut looked like she stuck her finger in an electrical socket. It was just good friend stuff, not meant for anyone else. But my mom had read it and called the school to complain about my private joke. I wanted to disappear into the floor. By lunch, Kyle wasn't talking to me. Neither was Jake. Word got around that my mom was reading everything, and suddenly nobody wanted to text me anymore. Some kids even blocked me. It was like my social life had a disease. And the disease was my mom. That night, I stared at my phone, feeling trapped. But then I noticed something. The tracking app worked both ways. It log every time someone access the account. I spent hours studying those logs, and what I found made my skin crawl. My mom wasn't just checking my phone during the day. She was logging in 1 a m, 2 a m, even 3 a m. She was forwarding my messages to her laptop. She was screenshotting my photos. She was living inside my phone 24 7. So I came up with a plan. I created a fake friend named Daniel, made up this whole persona, gave him a backstory. Even found some random photos online to use as his profile pic on a group chat with myself.

Genuinely, what is going on this week? There has been a school shooting in Denver. A girl got stabbed on the subway and no one helped her. A decomposing body found in D4V D's car. A man was beheaded at a Dallas motel. Charlie Kirk getting shot and killed at a university. And all on top of that, the 9 11 was 24 years ago today. As much as I hate Charlie Kirk and his decisions, no one deserves to get killed. Imagine what his wife and kids are feeling right now. His children can't grow up with their dad. His wife is now a single parent. I genuinely hate Charlie, but I can't imagine how his family is handling this right now. And apparently they witnessed it. The way the blood came out of his neck was genuinely traumatizing. The way his body went limp immediately was horrifying. But anyways, moving on to the D4 V D situation. He's been on tour for like what, a month now? He hasn't been in LA for like a month. And the body hadn't decomposed enough for it to be in that car for so long. The body was in there for three days, and the police haven't even made him a suspect. And plus he had a concert like yesterday, I'm pretty sure. But yeah, moving on to the girl that was stabbed. She was literally minding her business before she got stabbed. And as soon as she got stabbed, everyone Was so calm, like, hello, she needs help. There was literal blood dripping on the floor. I don't have much information on the other situations, but the fact that this is all happened in a week is honestly scary. Like, this month has just started. What's going on

And what's worse, when they finally manage to hear you, they say something completely different. For example, wait, you got ran over by a bus? How did you come up to that conclusion? Someone genuinely needs to study this, because these people cannot be real, truly out

My little sister had a crush on my husband, but what she didn't know was he's crazy in love. Ariana's been following Kevin around like a lost puppy since I married him two years ago, batting her eyelashes, accidentally showing up wherever we are wearing his favorite color blue, asking him about his hobbies, the whole desperate routine that makes family gathering off. It started innocent enough, family dinners where she'd sit next to him instead of me, commenting heart eyes emojis on all his Instagram posts, asking him to explain basic things like changing a tire or fixing a leaky faucet, stuff she definitely already knew how to do. Mom thought it was sweet that Ariana was bonding with her brother in law. Dad was oblivious, but I could see what was happening. Ariana's always been competitive with me since we were kids. When I got accepted to college, she suddenly wanted the same one. When I got my first boyfriend in high school, she spent months trying to get his attention. The past six months, it escalated into stalker territory. She'd text even directly about emergencies that required him coming over. When I was at work last month, she called crying about a break in that turned out to be her cat knocking over a plant. A month before, she claimed her car wouldn't start in a parking lot. Except when he got there, it started perfectly fine. Kevin always handled it lightly because he's a good guy. But I could see he was getting uncomfortable. He'd show me the text afterward, roll his eyes, make jokes about her desperation, but never wanted to be harsh. Since she's family, she's young and doesn't understand boundaries, he'd say she'll grow out of it. But Ariana's 23, not 13. She knows exactly what she's doing. Last weekend, she went nuclear, showed up Saturday morning at 9 a. M. In a tiny white sundress, restful makeup, hair done like a photo shoot, claiming she needed Kevin to move heavy furniture. I'm just so weak and helpless, she pouted, flexing her Crossfit arms. I need a big, strong man. I was upstairs doing laundry but could hear everything through the vents. Usually, I'd rescue Kevin from the awkwardness, but something made me stay. But maybe I wanted to see how far she'd take it. Oh, my God, Kevin, you're so muscular, she giggled, clearly touching his arm. Do you work out every day? I bet you could lift me with one hand. Wanna try? I rolled my eyes. This girl had zero shame. I kept folding clothes, waiting for Kevin's polite deflection. Instead, I heard him say, seriously, Ariana, can I tell you something important? My heart sank. Oh, god, here we go. Two years of marriage down the drain.

Bro, I just realized a way to steal legal if you just go to the buy one get one free section of the store, buy one item and get two. Then later on just return the item you paid for. Because think about it, if you return the original, get your money back, you still have the extra free item and it's completely legal because it was part of the deal. You're probably thinking they'll know you took two items, but there's a simple solution to that. Also, just go back the next day when a different employee is working there and they won't recognize you. Like, how has no one else thought of this yet?

That one friend who knows literally everyone. And I mean everyone. Bro, why is it that everywhere I go with you, it turns into a full on family reunion? Like, I can't even hang out with you in peace because every five steps, you're like, yo, bro, long time no see. Like, huh? Who even is that? We could be in a completely different city halfway across the world, and somehow you still know someone. Like, bro, we're at an airport in a different country, and you're dapping up the flight crew like y'all grew up together. And don't get me started on the grocery store. I'm just trying to buy snacks. And now you're catching up with your old coworker's cousin's best friend's dog trainer, bro. How? And the worst part, you remember every single detail about them, too. You're like, oh, yeah, he used to play soccer with me back in year five. Then he moved to Canada, but now he's back, and his sister married my other friend's uncle's barber. Like, what? My brain can't even hold my own passwords, and here you are remembering family trees. Meanwhile, I know, like, three people, and two of them are my own family. Honestly, at this point, you're not even my friend. You're a walking contacts list, bro. Got more connections than Wi Fi. Like, who are you, the president? If you have a friend like this, or if you are this friend, I got one question. How? Because Your social battery must be unlimited

My mom checked our location 14 times a day until it destroyed our family. Mom's eating breakfast scrolling through Facebook while Dad's counting out quarters for gas money when she announces we're all downloading life 3 60. We're two months behind on the electrical, but her friend says this app is the only way to keep family safe and honest. I'm 17 and work hard time at target. My dad does construction. We don't have time to be anything but safe and honest. She says if we have nothing to hide, we have nothing to fear. Which sounds like something a dictator would say, but whatever. She makes us install it right there at the table and checks that everyone's location is on. And I realize immediately what she doesn't understand about this app. Life 3 60 doesn't just show where you are. It shows your speed when driving, your phone battery, and sends notifications for everything, including when someone checks someone else's location. Mom works from home doing medical billing and has nothing but time to watch that app all day while dad and I are actually out in the world. Perfect. Now I'll know everyone's safe, she says. But what she means is now she can watch us like the musical jolly chimp from Toy Story. Her phone buzzes and she glances at it. Oh, shoot, I have a doctor's appointment in an hour. Dad offers to drive her, but she says no, she needs the car. All Day for Aaron. After months ago, my mom asked me to start covering for her when she goes out saying she's shopping or at the doctors. Whenever dad asks where she is, men lose interest when you mention women. Things she tell me she doesn't realize she just set herself up. Day one and my phone buzzes every 10 minutes with mom check your location while I'm at school. Dad text me she checked me 14 times this morning and we both realize she's literally sitting. They're refreshing the app constantly instead of working. Day 3 mom calls me screaming because the app says I was going 67 in a 65 and threatens to take my keys. So I start driving under the speed limit, which means I'm late to work and my manager writes me up. Dad gets stuck in traffic, won't go even 1 mile per hour over because mom will see. Shows up 30 minutes late to his job site and loses a client worth $2,000. Week two she sees I stopped at McDonald's for three minutes and lectures me about wasting money. Which is rich considering she was at the grocery store for four hours yesterday and came back with just milk saying nothing good on sale. Dad checks the app and asks her four hours at one store and mom glares at me like I should have warned her he was checking, but how can I when she's watching my every move? She used to Text me to cover for her now. She can't without dad seeing our messages about her lies. Week three, she's at a medical plaza until 11 p m. Dad mentions that's your fourth appointment this week. You okay? She snaps. Women's health is very thorough, but I've been to that clinic. They close at 6. That night, dad asks me privately, does your mom seem sick to you? I pull up her location history, all those medical building visits, and we're both hoping it isn't true. However, the electric Bill arrives, marked Final Notice, and dad slams it on the counter so hard the salt shaker falls over. I gave you $400 for that. And mom says, processing delay. It's fine. Dad and I are both staring at her location, chin pins on the map. Week 5, and dad texts me, I'm leaving work early. Something's not right. Meet me at the medical plaza. We both see Mom's been there since 11 a m, and it's now 6 p m. I tell my manager I'm sick and drive over. Dad's already there in the parking lot, looking at life. 3 60, zoom.

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the center of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding, I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up, he said. And I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself and I just can't deal with that stress on my wedding day. The line went quiet for like 10 seconds. Then Jake exploded. Are you serious right now you're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. He's basically family. I tried. To explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice, hoping he'd change his mind. He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, she says, shoving her phone in my face. Becca's Instagram story. She's posted like 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewelry. The caption on the last one says, can wait to celebrate love today with a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. She's coming anyway. Madison nods. Jake's outside right now arguing with your dad about it. He says he changed his mind and decided to bring her. I'm standing there in my wedding dress, half my makeup done, and I have to deal with.

How do I tell my crush I fell in love with her kids? I found my work crush share crying in the break room, looking completely stressed. My dad's in the hospital and I need to fly out tonight, but I can't find anyone to watch my kids. My ex won't answer. The babysitter I hired bailed. And I just, I can't afford to miss this flight, but I can't afford anything else either. She leaned against my shoulder crying even harder. I volunteered without thinking. I'll watch them, I said. Heart racing from how close she was to me. Are you serious? It's three kids, 3 for at least two weeks. Waved my hand around like a lovesick fool. How hard can it be? The kids showed up at my apartment that night with tons of suitcases. The oldest around 14, looked at her mom and said, really? Another boyfriend? Cher's face went red. He's just a friend from work. Camilla, the middle one, 10, rolled his eyes. The youngest, 7, wouldn't even look at me, stood in my doorway like they were being sentenced to prison. Cher hug them quickly, told them to be good and left for the airport. I stood there with three kids who clearly hated me and realized I was in way over my head. The first morning I woke up early to make them pancakes. When the oldest one, Camilla, laughed, she's not here, you know, you can stop trying, she said. Besides You're not her type. Mom doesn't date guys without kids. We've seen this a dozen times already. It hurt, but it wasn't a lie. Shares, coworkers, guys from her gym, men from dating apps, everyone wanted to play dad until they realized three kids meant actual work. And the kids really didn't make it any easier. From spilling drinks on my laptop to turning the TV up during important zoom meetings, they hated every second with me. Dude, just survive until she gets back, then ask her out. My friend told me that became the plan. Survive two weeks, do whatever to keep the kids happy, be the hero, finally land a date with share. But like most things, it doesn't always happen the way you want it to. Sometime within the second week, the middle kid, Murph, came home from school trying to hide a black eye. Before I could even ask, Camilla grabbed ice from the freezer and held it against his face. Just pretend you didn't see anything, she hold me coldly. I bent down beside them and asked in a kind but stern voice, tell me what happened. Just leave me alone, he said. Turning away, I shook my head. I'm not here to lecture you or get mad at you or do anything without your permission, not even tell your mom. But I need to know what happened. Murph blinked at me and frowned. Someone called me an orphan because I don't have a dad. I patted his head and walking away as calm as I could, even though all the blood in my body was boiling with anger. The next afternoon, I took a half day at work and showed up at their school in a rented GTR, strikingly white engine purring like a monster. I rolled down the window and waved wearing sunglasses and a black polo. Who's got the coolest dad now, I said loudly as Murph and his friends ran over excitedly. Murph watched his bully's jaw drop and quickly he hopped in. He rolled down the window and flipped him off, which was my signal to immediately drive off the middle school campus. Okay, I like the enthusiasm, but let's never tell your mother about this, I said. I picked up the other two kids and took them to in and out for a quick afternoon snack, then surprised them with a baseball game. Murph ate in a helmet full of nachos and I managed to snag a foul ball for little Celia. Not bad, old man, Camilla said, watching her siblings enjoy the game, we made sure to take pics with the car and at the stadium, all covered in ketchup and mustard. I sent everything to their mom with a caption, we wish you were here. After that, things between me and the kids sort of changed. When the youngest, Celia, had a nightmare and called for her mom, I sat beside her bed reading out fairy tales. Until she fell asleep. I made the kids meals and lunch box.

Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward. After three years of zero contact, the court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from in the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the place. Eleanor was packing the twins lunches for school, family photos covering our refrigerator, pictures of camping trips, birthdays, Christmas mornings, none included my ex. My ex froze staring at Eleanor. Who are you? Where are my kids? Skyler and Walter walked downstairs for breakfast, backpacks ready for school. They stopped cold seeing this stranger in Their kitchen. Who's that lady mom, Skyler asked Eleanor, genuinely confused. Walter squinted at my ex, trying to place her, wait, aren't you the woman from those old pictures in Dad's closet? My ex's face crumbled. Six years expecting to pick up where she left off, only to discover she'd been completely replaced. The kids she abandoned barely remembered her, and the man she thought would wait forever had built a beautiful new life. I came home, she whispered. This isn't your home anymore, I replied calmly, it hasn't been for six years. She looked around our kitchen. Eleanor's recipe cards on the counter, the kids artwork on the walls, our wedding photo by the coffee maker. Everything screamed happy family, and she wasn't part of it. The woman who left expecting everything to pause for her return realized that life had moved on completely without her. Her own children called another woman mom.

Entitled mother demanded that I give my daughter to my sister. I recently gave birth to twin girls. I had kept this a secret from my family to surprise them. A month before I gave birth, my sister's child tragically passed away from SIDS and my family mourned the loss of the baby. When I gave birth, my whole family visited me except for my sister and her husband. I understood because they were still grieving. News quickly spread that I had given birth to twins. My sister visited with her in laws. Her mother in law immediately said that god had sent another their baby for my sister, claiming one of my twins was a reincarnation of their lost child. I firmly told them that both babies were mine. They held my twins and looked at each other, convinced that one of them was indeed their lost baby. My husband quickly took our babies and to them out. Later that day, my mother visited and insisted I should give one of my twins to my sister because she was mourning. I refused, told her they are mine. The next morning we saw on our ring camera her mother in law was standing in front of our door at 3:00am praying. It's sent chills down my spine. I threatened them to leave us alone every day for one week. A dead bird that was gutted is on our porch and a red colored stain the sides of our home. My Husband and I knew right then we have to leave. My husband called the police and said they cannot do anything as somebody might be just playing with us. Red stain on the wall and our door was an animal's blood. They offered to file for a restraining order once we figured who did it. My husband was eager and knew who it was after we reviewed the footage of our ring camera. I told him not to since it's my sister's in laws and maybe talking to them will sort this out. I don't believe in this kind of arrangement. But I was wrong. After her mother in law's visit, I told my sister about her weird behaviour and it did scare us. I'm not sure if she ever said anything, but her mother in law kept coming back at exactly 3:00am, praying. She would stay on the porch, standing, whispering while her head tilted. My sister then told me that I shouldn't keep my own kids from her and that she should feel bad because she lost her child. She went on telling me what I would feel if I lost a child. She had been the favourite child and she gets everything all the time. It's just one time where things didn't favor her. After. My sister terrorized me every day, sending me thousands of messages and emails. One morning we found a dead bird on our porch, gutted as if someone had intentionally it. It went On for a week, I called my sister and told her that if her mother in law visited again, we would call the police. My sister never replied. A few days later, everyone including me, my twins and my husband started to get really sick. I felt like somebody had done something to us and I suspected it was her mother in law. My mother came to stay and help since we had been so sick. Not only that, my husband got into a car accident where someone rear ended him on the freeway, destroying our car. Thankfully, my husband wasn't seriously injured. The second one, we were lucky enough because we had our kids in the back. With my husband's quick reflexes, he was able to avoid the car on his right, which collided with a car in front of us, hitting another car, which resulted in two casualties. One day, I let my mother visit me to help with the chores. Same evening, my husband came home from work and woke me up, showing me footage from the ring camera. While I was resting, my mother had let my sister and her husband into our home. My sister then took one of the twins, cradled her and even breastfed her. They took family photos with my baby. I was alarmed and furious. I didn't hesitate to file a restraining order against my sister, her husband and my mother. Not only that, but I also discovered my mother had Put a sleeping pill in my soup. After my husband, right before taking the trash out, saw the box, which explains how I was knocked out for eight hours. I started to get really scared because they were doing everything they could to get my child. My husband decided we needed to leave our home and move somewhere else. We didn't stay for long, and

You know that one friend who just always shares their food with you, like you don't even have to ask. They'll literally take one bite and then hand it over, like, here, bro, try this. And honestly, that's real love right there because food, food is personal. If you're willing to split your fries with me, we're basically family. But sometimes they'll share in the most random ways. Like you're sitting there not even hungry and suddenly they're like, yo, have half of my sandwich and now I'm eating it just out of respect because how do you say no? They look at you like it's a sacred bond, like this is our moment. And it's always funny, too, because they'll give you the biggest piece of their food but then act like they're not hungry anymore. Like, bro, why did you even buy it if I'm the one eating most of it? You just spent $10 on food for both of us without even knowing. But honestly, those friends are different because in a world full of people who say, don't touch my plate, having someone who says, take some, I got you, that's special. That's not just friendship. That's family level loyalty. Ehhe.

At Dad's birthday, my brother announced, pack your bags, loser, this house is going up for sale. Everyone cheered and raised their glasses. I stepped outside and made one phone call. 10 minutes later, screaming started. See, two years ago when dad had his heart attack, I discovered something. They were three months behind on mortgage payments. The bank was for closing next week. My family had no idea. Dad was too proud to tell anyone. So I used my entire divorce settlement, $180,000, to buy the house at auction. I created an LLC called Clearwater Holdings and let them keep living there without telling them. I figured I'd transfer it back once they got stable again. Now my brother Marcus thinks he can just sell it and split the money. He's already called two realtors. The irony wasn't lost on me. For two years, I've been quietly paying property taxes, insurance and maintenance costs. Every time something broke, I'd anonymously arrange for repairs. The new roof last spring, that was me. The HVAC system that mysteriously got warranty coverage, also me. Marcus had been living rent free in a house I owned while constantly reminding everyone how successful he was compared to his loser sister. When I walked back inside, he was drawing renovation plans on napkins with his wife, Jennifer. We could add a wine cellar, he was saying, gesturing wildly with his beer, and a home theater, Jennifer added, her eyes practically blowing with dollar signs. Mom Was nodding enthusiastically. Oh, and we could finally get that kitchen island I've always wanted. Dad sat quietly in his chair looking uncomfortable but not saying anything. He'd always hated confrontation. My teenage nephew Tyler was on his phone, probably already shopping for the car Marcus had promised him from his inheritance share. Actually, I said calmly, walking back to the dining room table. I need to tell you something important. Just didn't even look up from his sketching. If you're gonna beg us to let you stay, save it, he laughed. Decisions made. Jenny already found us a realtor friend who can get us top dollar. Really, I said sitting down across from him. That's interesting because I just got off the phone with my attorney. Mom rolled her eyes dramatically. Alex, honey, you can't afford an attorney. Stop being so dramatic about this. James Morrison from Morrison and Associates. I can continued ignoring her comment. He specializes in real estate law. Dad finally looked up with interest. Why were you talking to a real estate attorney, sweetheart? Because I wanted to understand what happened when someone tries to sell a house they don't legally own. The room went completely silent. Even Tyler looked up from his phone. Marcus's pen stopped moving. What are you talking about? Mom and dad own this house. They've lived here for 30 years. They lived here for 30 years, I corrected calmly, but they haven't owned it for the past 14 months. Dad's Face had gone completely pale. Alex, what are you saying? I pulled out my phone and opened the email James had sent me. According to the county property records, this house is owned by Clearwater Holdings LLC. It was purchased at foreclosure auction 14 months ago for $165,000. Marcus stood up so fast his chair nearly fell over.

I had an affair with an Italian girl while I was married. Turns out I got her pregnant. I was so scared to ruin my marriage, I told her to go back to Italy to have the baby. Told, if you have it in Italy, I'll give you 25,000 up front, and I'll pay child support every month until the kid is 18. She was skeptical at first, but eventually she agreed. But then she was like, but how would you know when the baby is born? And honestly, that was a good question. So I thought about it for a second. I was like, well, when the baby is born, send me a postcard, and on the back of it write spaghetti. And I told her, I said, once I receive that post card, I start sending the child support money. Then one day, about nine months later, I come home to my confused wife. Soon as I walked in, she was like, already? There's this weird postcard made out out to you. And I was like, just give me it. I'll explain it later. And obviously she agreed. But when I read the card, I literally passed out, and I woke up three hours later in the hospital. When I woke up, I asked my wife if she still had the postcard with her, and she said yes. So I said, please give me that. I thought I was seeing things, but when I read the card again, Nah, it was serious. The card read spaghetti, spaghetti, spaghetti. Two with meatballs, one without. Send extra sauce.

Pretended to be my best friend's e girlfriend for 2 years and made his life hell. You ever get betrayed so bad it doesn't just hurt, it rewrites you. That was me. My ex best friend Eli stabbed me in the back in a way I still don't fully understand. We've been close since we were kids, shared everything, laughed until our stomachs hurt. I thought we were brothers. Then senior year came around and I found out he'd been using me. Not in the he copied my homework way. No, this was deeper. He took everything I told him in confidence about my anxiety, my insecurities, my family stuff, my parents messy divorce and used it to build clout with a group of people I thought hated me. Turned my personal life into a punchline. I confronted him and he just smirked and said, grow a thicker skin, dude. It's just jokes. That night I decided to become someone else. It started off stupid. I wanted revenge. Nothing deep, just enough to embarrass him. I made a fake profile of a girl and named her J. It started off small, like turning my pictures into a female version, setting up a fake Instagram. My plan was simple, get him to say some pathetic flirty stuff and then leak it to the school. But Eli fell fast, faster than I expected. And the more he fell, the more I leaned in. What was at first meant to be a two Week job quickly turned full time. By week three, I was using a voice changer to call him. He'd call me every night before bed. Obviously I needed some compensation, so he'd cash app me 10 bucks every call. He'd say stuff like I've never felt this comfortable with anyone. He opened up in ways I'd never seen before. The way he talked to her, the way he needed her. And I started to realize something. He never respected me, but this version of me, this soft voiced, smiling, wide eyed girl from a few towns over, he worshipped her. What started as a joke stretched into weeks, then months. I'd spend hours each day crafting conversations, sinking voice filters, sending selfies, managing multiple burner accounts. I created playlists, family stories, fake college plans. I Learned everything about his insecurities, his fear of being alone, of not being good enough, of being forgotten. And I used all of it. A year in, I realized I'd gone too far. This wasn't revenge anymore. This was something else. I wasn't just catfishing him. I was breaking him and myself slowly and quietly. But the worst part was that I didn't stop. That's when the real revenge started. Jade became distant.

What's the dumbest reason your daughter stopped talking to you? Oh, honey, let me tell you about the time my daughter didn't talk to me for two whole weeks because I betrayed her trust over a damn chicken nugget. So my daughter Lila, she's 14, has the attitude of a Beverly Hills housewife and the budget of a toddler. This girl acts like she's the CEO of the household. Tells me things like, mom, please don't embarrass me in front of my friends. Just stand still and blink like, ma'am, you live in my uterus rent free for nine months. Show some respect. Anyway, she decides she's going vegan. Great. I support her. I buy tofu, almond milk, overpriced plant nuggets that taste like regret. The whole shebang. Do I understand it? No, but I'm a supportive queen. But then one night, it's 1:00am, I'm watching reality TV in the dark, and I get hungry. I open the freezer and see those dino shaped chicken nuggets she begged for last year and never ate. So I pop, like, four in the air fryer. I'm minding my business, living my best life, and guess what? I forget to hide the evidence. Next morning, she walks into the kitchen, sniffs the air like a bloodhound, and goes, did you eat meat in this house? I said, uh, maybe. She gasps like, I just committed war crimes. You ate dead animals while I was sleeping? I said, baby girl, they were shaped like dinosaurs. They're barely meat. Calm down. She grabs her reusable water bottle, slams it on the counter, and yells, this is why the planet's dying, Because of people like you who can't control their midnight cravings! I said, okay, Greta Thunberg, relax. She storms off to her room and text me from down the hall, we're not speaking. This is a betrayal. I text back, fine, more dino nuggets for me. She leaves me on read y'all. Two weeks he wouldn't speak to me. Not even when I stubbed my toe and screamed so loud the neighbours checked on me. She just walked past me with her Hydro flask and judgmental aura. But then get this. One day I come home early from work, I walk into the kitchen, and there she is, standing in front of the microwave holding a plate with three dino nuggets. She's caught mid bite. We lock eyes. Time freezes. She goes, they don't count if they're Dinosaur shaped. I said, excuse me? She wipes her mouth like a criminal and goes, don't tell dad. I said, oh, I'm telling everyone. She bribes me with her leftover Starbucks gift card and begs for mercy. I post the photo in our family group chat anyway. Caption our little activist caught mid murder her grandpa.

I removed my daughter's bedroom door because she won't stop slamming it. It started about six months ago. Every argument, every little thing that didn't go her way, slam. Every time I asked her to do dishes, slam. When I told her she couldn't go to some party where I knew they'd be drinking, slam! The sound would shake the whole upstairs. My coffee mug fell off my nightstand twice from the vibrations. My husband Dave, kept telling me to ignore it. He'd say, kids go through phases. She'll grow out of it. Easy for him to say, since he's usually at work when most of the slamming happens. I'm the one working from home, trying to take client calls while slam! Echoes through the house. The breaking point came on a Tuesday. Emma wanted to borrow my car to drive to her friend Jesse's house. I said no because she got a speeding ticket the week before, and we agreed her driving privileges were suspended. She started screaming about how unfair I was, how I never trust her, how all her friends think I'm psycho. Then she stomped upstairs and slam! But this time was different. This time I heard something crack. Went up to check, and there was a split running down the door frame. The wood was actually damaged. That door had been slammed so hard and so many times that it was breaking the house. I stood there staring at that crack, and something just snapped. In me, I marched to the garage, grabbed Dave's screwdriver set, and went back upstairs. Emma was inside her room blasting music, probably expecting me to yell at her through the door like usual. Instead, I started unscrewing the hinges. It took me about 10 minutes. Emma didn't even notice until I was lifting the door off the frame. Then her music stopped real quick. Mom, what are you doing? She called out. Solving a problem, said carrying her door downstairs to the garage. She appeared at the top of the stairs in her pajamas, mouth hanging open. You can't take my door. I need privacy. You lost your privileges when you damaged the house, I told her. Privacy is earned, not guaranteed. The next few days were interesting. Emma tried everything. She hung a bed sheet across the doorway, which I took down. She moved her dresser to block the opening, so I moved it back. While she was at school, she even tried staying at her friend's house. Jess's mom called me asking what was going on. By day four, Emma was sitting on her bed when I got home from the grocery store. No music, no phone. Just sitting there. This is embarrassing. She. What if someone comes over? Then maybe you'll think twice before destroying property. I said I wasn't destroying anything. I was just mad. The door frame says otherwise. That's when she actually looked at the crack she'd made. I could see her face. Change. When she realised she'd actually damaged something. Day seven was when things got real. Emma's boyfriend Tyler came over to work on some school project. I watched from the kitchen as he walked upstairs, expecting to go into her room and

Deleted my friend's wedding photos in front of them. My best friend Jess was getting married and asked me to be her photographer. I've been doing photography for like three years now, mostly just for fun and some side cash, but nothing super professional. She said she trusted me more than some random person and honestly couldn't afford a real wedding photographer anyway. The wedding was beautiful. I spent the entire day running around getting shots of everything. We're getting ready, walking down the aisle, the first kiss, all the family photos. I was exhausted, but felt good about it. I probably took like 800 photos that day. After the reception, Jess pulled me aside and said she couldn't wait to see them. It was literally glowing with excitement. I told her I'd edit them and have them ready in a week. That's when things got weird. Two days later, Jess texted me asking if I could rush the photos because her and her husband Jake wanted to post them on social media. I said sure, no problem. But then she started texting me every single day asking for updates. Like multiple times a day. Then she called me crying, saying her mom was asking about the photos and could I please just send her like five unedited ones? I sent her a few, thinking that would calm her down. Wrong. The next day she showed up at my apartment unannounced. She had Jake with her and they both looked Stressed, she said they needed to talk about the photos. Apparently, Jess's mom had been showing the unedited photos I sent to family members, and now everyone was asking why the photographer didn't know how to use proper lighting. Jess said she was embarrassed and needed me to fix them immediately. I explained that editing takes time, and I was working on them, but she cut me off and said she'd found another photographer who could fix my mistakes for $500. She wanted me to send her all the raw files so this other person could edit them instead. I was honestly hurt. These weren't even bad photos. The lighting was a little dim in a few shots because the venue was dark, but nothing that couldn't be fixed in editing. That's literally what editing is for. But here's where it gets really messed up. When I hesitated about sending the raw files, Jake stepped in and said they

Hacked my roblox account so I made sure he never experienced his childhood. He thought it was funny. Some 14 year old troll with greasy fingers and too much time. He hacked my roblox account, took my limiteds, deleted my builds, sold my dominoes for 4 bucks and a fortnite skin. He even renamed my Avatar crybaby 1 2. 3 then messaged my friends lol. I'm quitting because I peed the bed and logged out like he won. Cute. So I pulled on my hoodie, cracked my knuckles, and logged into his real life. Step 1 trace the rat. He used a VPN, but he forgot his Roblox was linked to an old Gmail. And that Gmail was tied to a Pinterest account which had his mom's full name, school photos, and boom. Home address. Yes, found it through his mom's Facebook with screenshots of his discord DMS.

Took a three hour nap every day and expected my husband to look after the kids and only wake me up for emergencies. I work night shift at the hospital as a nurse, getting home around 7:00am completely dead on my feet. My husband Jake works from home doing some tech stuff, so I figured he could handle our two kids, Mia who's 5 and Connor who's 3, while I caught up on sleep from 2 to five PM every day. Jake seemed fine with it at first. He take the kids to the park, make them snacks, put on cartoons. I'd wake up refreshed and ready to handle dinner in bedtime. It worked for like three months and Jake started getting weird about it. He'd wake me up for the dumbest stuff. Connor wanted a specific cup, Mia couldn't find her favorite hair tie. They were being too loud during his work calls. I was like, dude, these aren't emergencies. I specifically said emergencies. Only one. Tuesday I woke up to Jake shaking me at 3:30. I was so groggy and confused. He was like Mia fell off her bike and scraped her knee pretty bad. I shot up thinking she needed stitches or something. No, it was literally just a scrape. Like the kind you put a band aid on and kiss better. I was so mad. I told him that was an emergency and went back to sleep. But I could hear him slamming cabinets downstairs breaking Point came last Friday. I've been up all night dealing with three different patients in crisis, then got home and crashed hard. Around three PM, Jake burst into our room yelling emergency! Emergency! I literally thought someone was dying. I ran downstairs in my pajamas and found both kids sitting calmly at the kitchen table eating goldfish crackers. Connor had somehow gotten permanent marker on his forehead. Just a little squiggle. Mia was completely fine watching Bluey on the iPad.
